characters: WHEN WE CUT BACK TO GAWAIN

dialogues.speaker: A BOAT
dialogues.text: Specifically, a garbage scow. We see it from ON HIGH, chugging down the placid but migh Mississippi. Head credits play over COVERAGE of the garbage scow. No s except for an incongruously heroic score. The COVERAGE is a little rough, coarse-grained; along wit the overbearing score it almost suggests an industrial fi rather than a feature. One piece of sound -- the toot of the boat's horn -- is  obviously library. And not a new library either. The garbage scow passes under a bridge spanning the broad sluggish waters, and proceeds on to its landfill, a steam river island. Disturbed gulls and other scavenger birds r from where they were picking through trash. Their squawks like the boat horn, are not quite believable as SYNC. The head credits end as the anthemic music resolves.

dialogues.speaker: AN OLD HOUND DOG
dialogues.text: lies on the weather-grayed and -roughened planking of a f porch. The porch is half-shaded from the noonday sun. It quiet except for the chirr of heat bugs, close by, and, v distant, many voices in chorus, engaged in divine worship a Baptist church sufficiently far away that vagaries of b fan them in and out of audibility. We once again hear the toot of the scow's horn, distant n and played as real, not slapdash effect. At this, the dog lifts his nose to catch the breeze, sniffs, and then, whi lowers his head to the floor and covers his snout with hi forepaws. He huffs briefly and goes to sleep. We DRIFT UP to show that the dog is sleeping before the

dialogues.speaker: SAUCIER WORM STORE
dialogues.text: Your source for worms, lures, etcetera, etcetera... We TRAVEL OVER TO REVEAL that the modest one-story struct houses two establishments; its other front door leads to SAUCIER MUNICIPAL BUILDING. A campaign sign in the window on the municipal side shows black man of late middle-age beaming and giving the viewe thumbs-up: RE-ELECT WAYNE WYNER SHERIFF/He Is Too Old to Go to Work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear snoring on top of a low, steady hissing sound. We are DRIFTING toward the door of the lock-up, which sta open. The small cell is empty, its bed neatly made.

dialogues.speaker: A KEY
dialogues.text: We are ARCING slowly around a jailer's key on a ring that hangs from a nail. The OFFSCREEN snoring and whirring  continues. The TRACK'S SHIFTING ANGLE now makes the light catch a sp web spun between the key and the wall.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE SCANNER
dialogues.text: We DRIFT across the face of the radio. The peaceful stead hissing jumps in louder at the CUT: it is uninterrupted: transmissionless, crimeless, misdemeanorless idle radio h The snoring is also louder here. As we TRAVEL OFF the rad we are COMING ONTO a pair of feet propped up on the deskt They belong to SHERIFF WYNER, tipped back in his chair,  fingers laced on his chest, head lolling forward. As the MOVING CAMERA FINALLY ENDS on him, there is the ri of a telephone -- muffled, not present. It nevertheless rouses the sheriff who almost strangles o snore as he awakes, and then rocks forward to pick up his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Wyner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The muffled ringing continues; the sheriff looks, puzzled at the phone. Now the ringing stops and we hear a muffled voice next door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheriff replaces the phone, leans back again, adjusts his hat, and is about to go back to sleep when we hear th front door open. The sheriff looks and reacts with genuine, if momentary,  fear. He manages to compose himself and give the intruder a smi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon, Miz Munson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entering is an elderly black woman in a floral print dres and fruited bonnet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon, Sheriff. You know the  Funthes boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mackatee Funthes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no, WeeMack! Mackatee's eldest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, believe I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's a good boy but he done  gone down to the Costco in Pascagoula  and got hisself a blastah -- and he  been playin' that music!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyner is not sure where this is going:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Left my wallet in El Segundo!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Songs like that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hippity-hop music!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know they call it hippity-hop  music, but it don't make me wanna go  hippity-hop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ma'am--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Othar don't like that music  neither!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Wyner now displays an exaggerated solicitousness:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been disturbin' Othar then, has  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could it help but do! That kind  of music! You know what they call  colored folks in them songs? Have  you got any idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIGGAZ! I don't wanna say the word.  I won't say it twice, I'll tell you  that. I say it one time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the course a swearin' out my  complaint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes'm--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIGGAZ! Two thousand years after  Jesus! Thirty years after Martin  Luther King! The age of Montel! Sweet  lord a-mercy, izzat where we at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-mm--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WeeMack down to Pascagoula buyin' a  big thumpy stereo player?! So he can  listen to that word in the house  next to mine? Sheriff, you gotta  help that boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta take an innarest! EXTEND  that helpin' hand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dubious) Well, we're here to help...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well God bless ya. Don't wanna be  tried and found wantin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many many tunkalow parzen, Sheriff  Wyner. Many many tunkalow parzen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many what ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been tried and found wanting.  Don't want that writin' on the wall!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ma'am--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feast a Balthazar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John The Apostle said: Behold there  is a stranger in our midst, come to  destroy us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson closes the door behind her. She wags a paper and mutters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a good man. Just needs  instruction. Dog, you in peoples'  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog stirs with a whine and ambles off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a neatly tended garden. It is the last house on a st of other similarly modest but well maintained homes; beyo it the street disappears down a bluff. The empty space be suggests a wide river, and indeed we can see the top of a anchored, gaudily painted paddle-boat poking over the ris The paddle-boat is apparently anchored at the near bank o the river. Mrs. Munson is entering by the gate. She stops in the gar and stoops to pull a tiny weed marring the otherwise perf row of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. MUNSON HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson lets herself in. A cat lopes up to her, the b around its neck tinkling, and leans mewing into her leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need somethin' to eat, Angel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson hand-cranks a can opener around a tin of cat  food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm... gizzards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat paces back and forth between her legs, leaning in them and purring, responding to the snap of tin as the co comes off the can. The can contains cubed processed gizzard in a gelatinous  medium like the stuff that clings to gefilte fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Above the fireplace is an oil portrait of a serious-looki black man of late middle-age with a neatly groomed mustac starting to gray. A couple of candles sit on the mantel b the portrait, giving it the semblance of a shrine. Mrs. Munson enters and lights the candles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othar, I went'n complained about  WeeMack, I hope it'll do some good.  That boy hangin' by a thread! Over  the pit! Fiery pit! "I Left My Wallet  in El Segundo"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes out the match and sits in a rocker and takes u her knitting. As she sits she gives an audible groan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Sixty-seven years of life, forty- six years of marriage, you mean to  tell me you never one time suffered  from piles? It's the human condition,  most humans anyway. Like that ball  player said: world's got two kinds  of folks -- them that's got piles  and them that's gonna get 'em. But  you was always healthy as an ox...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the distant moan of a riverboat horn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Passed on before you got piles.  Mmmmhmm. Thank the Lord you wasn't  sick. You don't wanna sicken 'n die.  No, you wanna pass nice 'n peaceful...  go to sleep one night, wake up in  the glory land... woof...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gust of wind hums under the eaves; the candles below th portrait flicker. As Mrs. Munson looks around the room,  vaguely towards the ceiling, sensing a negative aura, the cat arches its back and hisses. At this moment the doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well who's that now, Pickles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grunts as she hoists herself out of the chair.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. MUNSON HOUSE
dialogues.text: She opens the door-- A draft--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The candles below the portrait of Othar go out, sending u thin wisps of smoke.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. MUNSON HOUSE
dialogues.text: The cat shrieks and bolts out the door, past the man on t stoop: GOLDTHWAIT HIGGINSON DORR, III. He is a middle-aged Southern gentleman wearing a panama h and a cape over a cream-colored suit. He has dark circles under his eyes. The smile he attempts, mournful yet court is wiped away by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PICKLES!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go get 'im!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go get Pickles, I didn't let 'im  out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tasting the name) Pickles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr walks down the stoop followed by the old lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he's up the tree again. Your  gonna have to shimmy on up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so terribly sorry, madam. But  won't the feline eventually tire of  his lonely perch and, pining for his  master's affection, return on his  own initiative?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? No, he won't come down less you  fetch him. He'd set there til Gabriel  blows his horn if someone didn't  shimmy up. Up with you now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then couldn't we perhaps offer  him kitty treats and enticements, or  if not foodstuffs perhaps squeaky  little toys of the kind formerly  manufactured in Hong Kong but now  produced in the other so-called  "Little Tigers"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His fingers form the quotes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...of the Pacific Rim? The point  bein', do we have to actually ascend  the tree--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don't want no doubletalk. If  you ain't gonna fetch him down I  guess I gotta call the po-lice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face darkens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ain't gonna be happy. Every  time they come fetch him down they  swear they won't do it no more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr casts his hat aside and starts awkwardly climbing th tree. He gasps as he climbs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need to call the authorities. I  did this often as a youth -- why, I  was a positive lemur... Here, kitty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat backs away down a branch, arching its back and  hissing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't upset him, now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr, on his stomach, inches after the cat, grunting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't dream of it... harmless  little felix domesticus... Come to  G.H...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The branch breaks, hinging down to slam Dorr face-first i the trunk, from where he drops the rest of the way to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othar's portrait, upside-down, seems to be looking bemuse down on us. An OBJECTIVE ANGLE shows Dorr lying on the couch, a damp  washcloth on his forehead, eyes rolled back to look at th picture. Mrs. Munson is entering with a cup of tea. Dorr swings hi feet out to sit up and accept the tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thank you, madam, for your act of  kindness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you let him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I certainly did and I do apologize  no end. Allow me to present myself,  uh, formally: Goldthwait Higginson  Dorr, Ph.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, like Elmer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beg your pardon, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fudd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no, Ph.D. is a mark of academic  attainment. It is a degree of higher  learning bestowed, in my case, in  recognition of my mastery of the  antique languages of Latin and Greek.  I also hold a number of other advanced  degrees including the baccalaureate  from a school in Paris, France, called  the Sorbonne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munson chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sore bone, well I guess that's  appropriate. You ever study at Bob  Jones University?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have not had that privilege.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bible school, only the finest  in the country. I send them five  dollars every month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very gener--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on their mailing list. I'm an  Angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They list my name in the newsletter,  every issue. I got the literature  here, you wanna examine it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps when my head has recovered  from its... buffeting. Mrs. Munson,  are you at all curious as to why I  darkened your door, as the expression  has it, on this lovely camelia-scented  morn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wondering, til you let Pickles  out. Then in all the excitement--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I quite understand. The fact is that  I saw the sign on your window  advertising a room to let, and it is  the only such sign among the houses  of this charming, charming street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got a room. I'm lookin' for  a quiet tenant. Fifteen dollars a  week

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I quite understand. Madam, you are  addressing a man who is quiet -- and  yet not quiet, if I may offer a  riddle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sets down the teacup and rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Perhaps you can show me the room,  Mrs. Munson, and allow me to explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you can see the room, but I  don't like double-talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson precedes him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, madam, I am currently on  sabbatical from the institution where  I teach -- the University of  Mississippi at Hattiesburg. I am  taking a year off to indulge my  passion -- I don't believe that is  too strong a word -- for the music  of the Renaissance. I perform in --  and have the honor of directing -- a  period instrument ensemble that  performs at Renaissance fairs and  other cultural fora...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter a small bedroom. There is a small bed on a bra frame, a chair, a wash basin, and cheerful yellow chintz  drapes on the window. Dorr appreciatively takes it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...thoo-out central and southern  Mississippi. We perform on the  instruments for which the music was  originally composed, in the belief  that... that... Why, this is lovely...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. You got some kind of  band?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr once again wiggles quotes with his fingers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The word "band" would be, in this  context, something of an anachronism.  Though we do play together -- hence  the word "ensemble" -- the nature of  the music is such that one would  hesitate to apply the epithet "band"  with its connotations of jangling  rhythm and ear-popping amplification.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't play hippity-hop, "I  Left My Wallet in El Segundo," songs  with the titles spelt all funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam, I shudder. I quake. The  revulsion I feel for modern popular  music, and all other manifestations  of contemporary decay, is, I have no  doubt, the equal of y'own. Why, we  play music that was composed to the  greater glory of God. Devotional  music. Church music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gospel music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well-inspired by the gospels,  certainly. The vintage, of course,  is no more recent than the Rococo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rococo, huh? Well, I guess that'd be  okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I certainly don't propose to  inflict our rehearsals on you. May I  enquire -- do you have a root cellar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr ducks while descending the steep, narrow stair in or to avoid an overhead beam. He is followed by Mrs. Munson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, yes, this looks promising...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls on a hanging string to light a bare bulb overhea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little dank, ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, indeed, but that only improves  the acoustics...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He experimentally claps his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Marvelous. These earthen walls  are ideal for baffling the higher  registers of the, uh, lute and, uh,  sackbutt. That's why so much music  of the cinquecento was played in  crypts and catacombs. Yes, this will  do nicely...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dry-washes his hands with enthusiasm, but his tone rem mournful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This is perfect. This is more  than perfect. I can scarcely contain  my glee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You containing it okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to peel cash out of a large, well-worn billfold

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allow me to pay you a week in advance.  Allow me to pay you two weeks in  advance. Allow me to pay you a month  in advance. I cannot countenance the  thought of these charming apartments  being tenanted by someone  unappreciative of their special je  ne sais quoi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be a shame.

dialogues.speaker: A GARBAGE CART
dialogues.text: On the cart is a boombox. It is playing "I Left My Wallet El Segundo." It is being pushed through a casino empty of customers. As the cart stops and a wastebasket is emptied into it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta peel this shit out sticks  to the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shows two youngish black men in the khaki uniforms of  custodians. Emptying the wastebasket is WEEMACK-MACKATEE  FUNTHES. He is instructing GAWAIN MACSAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You wouldn't believe this shit,  sometimes even out here on the casino  floor you gonna find sanitary napkin  shit stuck there, Tucks, I don't  know what the fuck people do while  they're gambling here man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't peelin' funky shit with my  human hands, man. That's a  prescription for disease and viruses  and shit, attackin' y'insides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they roll on we see more of the gambling floor, which on something less than the scale of a Las Vegas casino. T floor is not yet open and dealers stack and count chips a the tables, pit bosses with clipboards looking over their shoulders. Other dealers strap on visors and sleeve garte preparing to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta do it. Mr. Gudge checks  everything. Man is a motherfuck.  Shit -- looka this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a furtive look around he plucks a chip from the nex wastebasket and slips it in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You keep an eye out, man. I found  a hundred-dollar chip once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck that, man. I ain't pawin' through  used Tucks for a fi' dollar chip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said it was a hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, your guts gonna turn to soup'n  leak outcha fuckin' asshole.

dialogues.speaker: SERVICE HALL
dialogues.text: The cart jitters loudly on the dimpled plastic floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This tunnel leads back onto land. To  the office for all the people work  for Mannex. Mannex Corporation. Owns  the Lady Luck 'n three other boats...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men are entering a windowless fluorescent-lit off area. A row of wooden office doors and one heavy steel do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This is where they think on their  corporate shit, Gudge and them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops to empty a wastebasket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The lights is ugly but it ain't  as many Tucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bangs on the steel door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...YO, motherfuck! Lemme in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the password?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiss my ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a deep chuckle and the door, steel reinforced, sw open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men enter, WeeMack nodding at the security man  (ELRON).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where they count the dough.  You try to take any of it Elron there  shoot your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again the security man chuckles. WeeMack picks up some fa food wrappers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This place is a fuckin' pigsty.  You a pig, man, nothin' but a squeaky  ol' motherfuckin' pig...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elron chuckles. He is an enormously fat man; his chuckles come from deep, deep in his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You got fuckin' Kocoa Krispies in  ya uniform man, still got breakfast  there and you eatin' motherfuckin'  lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elron uses one hand to swipe crumbs off his uniform shirt chuckling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You a disgrace before motherfuckin'  God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elron chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You a motherfuck-- oh, hello Mr.  Gudge, how we be this mornin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man in a buttoned white shirt nods at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funthes. How's the new man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is a cleaning motherfucker, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a ruin of a field; charred trees point bare and gna limbs toward a gray sky; smoke drifts across the desolate waste. Something is bounding towards us from the deep background We BOOM DOWN as it approaches: a bulldog, running avidly  toward us on its stumpy little legs. An OFFSCREEN male voice (CLARK PANCAKE):

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One, Mountain!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an explosion that showers dirt in front of the d and makes it veer. Something strapped around the dog's ne bounces as he runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Scrub two! Scrub three! Four,  Mountain!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another explosion makes the dog veer back so that it once again bears on us. The thing that has been bouncing aroun its neck flies off. Our CONTINUING BOOM DOWN has brought us to ground level j as the dog arrives in front of us to feed at a dog food b in the foreground. The yellow plastic bowl has a K-Ration logo facing us. We hear another OFFSCREEN voice (DIRECTOR):

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut, goddamnit. His canteen fell  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Director's feet enter in the foreground. He hooks the dogs belly with one foot and hoists it roughly away from bowl. We

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DIRECTOR. He scowls down at the animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Props!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man in a Hemingway field-jacket with multiple pockets, also a loaded utility belt, trots up toward him, his belt jangling as he runs. This is CLARK PANCAKE. Pancake is a florid beer-bellied man in his late fifties. has a full blond-grey Grizzly Adams beard and wears multi pocketed shorts that form an ensemble with his Hemingway  jacket. The director is angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The goddamn thing's canteen fell  off. It would have been a good take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake is unperturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay. We're prepared for that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hits a button on the radio on his belt and talks into headset:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Mountain, bring Otto with the  apparatus.

dialogues.speaker: PULLING ANOTHER BULLDOG
dialogues.text: He strains at his lead, muscling forward as quickly as hi minder and his own stumpy little legs will allow. He peers through the two goggly eyeholes of an antique le gas mask, its pignose breathing apparatus covering his ow snout. His phlegmy breathing is amplified by the device. We TILT UP the lead to show his minder, MOUNTAIN GIRL. Sh is a solid woman in her late forties with freckles beginn to merge into age spots. Her long straw-colored hair is  tightly braided into Heidi pigtails bound with red ribbon Otherwise her dress is unadorned. The director squints at the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake's manner is professorial:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: World War I vintage gas mask. It's  authentic. Strapped on, of course,  so it can't fall off. The animal is  free to be as active as he wants,  doesn't inhibit his movement, and I  think it really sells the whole  doughboy thing--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like a fucking joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake stares at the director for a moment and, though n doing anything, makes a sound of concentrated effort:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Nnnnrnff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The director squints at him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake comes out of his trance, or whatever it was:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, nothing, uh... you're absolutely  right, the gas mask is a whimsical  concept--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell does it eat when it  gets to the Kennel Rations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog looks up from person to person as each speaks,  twisting its neck to peer through the eyeholes. Its breat is growing louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're absolutely rightВ–-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let the client see this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not, that would be  inappropriate--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or the Humane fucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog gets down on its knees, slowly, like a camel,  breathing ever more loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll shut the fucking spot down,  Pancake. Put the goddamn canteen  back on. That says he's a soldier.  Dented tin canteen. Just tie the  damn thing to his collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog flops over into the mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easiest thing in the world. I just  thought -- but the canteen is much  better. Good concept. Let's go with  that--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog has started to convulse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's uh... Just breathe  normally, Otto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fucking dog can't breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he can breathe, that thing is --  just breathe normally, Otto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog's breath is rasping and horrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fucking dog cannot breathe! Get  that fucking thing off him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Easiest thing in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stoops and fiddles at the straps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It's on good and tight, I, uh...  Just breathe normally, Otto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts thumping at his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the fucking thing off him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't have my Leatherman. Mountain!  Give me your Leatherman! Chop chop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the fucking thing off him! Chitra,  make sure the Humane fucker doesn't  come over here! Bring him to craft  services!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he makes to scoop up the dog:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea! Ice water, treats-В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the dog, you idiot! The Humane  fucker! Distract him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right! Of course!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes back to work on the mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god, he's bleeding!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's me -- I -- the  Leatherman... here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hand gouting blood, he finally manages to get the gas mask off. A crowd is starting to gather and gape. The director bark at a grip:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put up a couple solids here -- I  don't want the client seeing this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake thumps on the inert dog's chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Otto!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otto is fucking dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mountain, have electric run me a  stinger! Don't give up on me, Otto!  Mountain, I need two live leads!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More people crowd in to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark, the gennie's a hundred yards  away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamnit! Otto's gonna have brain  damage in about ninety seconds! Okay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls the dog's lips back, exposing its teeth and slob tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Kiss of life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sucks in a deep breath and starts mouth-to-mouthing th beast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are looking out from inside a football helmet; we hear the super-present breathing of the helmet's occupant. Jus over the breathing we can hear the muffled shouting of a  snap count. We are in a crouch position looking downfield. At the cal of "Hike!" we and everyone on the field spring into actio We sprint downfield, the breathing becoming even louder. very big person downfield is sprinting toward us. After several yards, still on the move, we PAN quickly ar to look back for the quarterback. Barely visible among  converging bodies, he is releasing the football toward so else. Easing up on the run we PAN BACK around to look downfield just as the oncoming defender is upon us and -- CRUNCH -- slams into us. A STROBING PAN leaves us looking up at the sky. Our loud breathing has stopped. After a long beat the breathing resumes with a raggedy la inhale. It continues irregularly. Another helmeted player appears above us to peer down into our helmet. He extends hand to help us up.

dialogues.speaker: HUDDLE
dialogues.text: We are looking back and forth around the circle at our  gathered teammates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delta thirty-seven. On four!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All, with a simultaneous hand clap:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh!

dialogues.speaker: LINE OF SCRIMMAGE
dialogues.text: Lined up opposite us is a snarling defender. Once again, over loud breathing, we can just hear the sho count. At "Hike!" we straighten to meet the defensive lineman lu at us. His mouthpiece clatters against ours and in horrif CLOSE-UP he strains against us, his animal gurgles of eff audible over our own ragged breath. With a primal roar from the defenseman our POV tips back up, BOOMING DOWN to stop with a CRUNCH against the ground staring up. Once again our breathing has stopped. After a beat a foot is planted on our helmet as a looming running back steps on us in his charge downfield. He is  pursued by defenders some of whom leap over us and some o whom by the sound of it step on various body parts.

dialogues.speaker: HUDDLE
dialogues.text: The same back-and-forth PAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Epsilon twenty-two! You the  man!... Hey! BUTTHEAD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This brings our wandering attention PANNING back to the  quarterback:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very, very present VOICE (HUDSON):

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me the man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh!

dialogues.speaker: LINE OF SCRIMMAGE
dialogues.text: The same breathing and count. On "Hike!" we sprint downfield. The same distant defender sprinting toward us. We hear low but very present a dismayed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unh... oh no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our breathing is torn by rasping wheezes of effort as we  continue to run. We look back. Every player is looking directly at us. A huge spiralling football coming at us -- too close, too soon -- and--

dialogues.speaker: BONK
dialogues.text: It bounces off our mouth guard and flies up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are looking forward just as

dialogues.speaker: CRUNCH
dialogues.text: We are hit by the defender. We once again land face-up. Very steeply FORESHORTENED, right over us, we see the def juggling the live ball. With a moan, our own hand reaches weakly up towards the b and the high, distant defender. He finally gathers in the ball and securely tucks it, and starts back upfield. We climb wearily to our feet. We look back upfield just i time to see the defender start an elaborate victory dance the end zone. He pauses for a moment to point a gloved ha directly at us, then resumes his strut. Shouting from the sidelines brings our PANNING attention  over. The coach, face twisted with fury, is shouting at us and  using his clipboard to wave us off the field. We trot toward the sidelines. All of our teammates stare at us В–- some in shock, some anger, some in pity. At the sideline bench our POV swings round as we seat our A hand reaches up to the mouth guard to pull off the helm and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our first OBJECTIVE SHOT as the player (HUDSON) finishes  pulling off his helmet. He is a big blond boy. His entire body, including his face, is solidly built. An offscreen Voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hudson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy, Hudson, turns to look, and we cut to one last

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The COACH is striding up, swinging his clipboard at the  camera: with a loud CRUNCH! it brings on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a typical sunbaked concrete strip mall with a Seven Eleven, a launderette, and a Hi-Ho Donut. The Hi-Ho Donut sign shows a pink donut with sprinkles and says in much  smaller lettering: And Croissants. A beat-up Impala pulls into the lot, pulsing hip-hop musi After a long rumbling idle the ignition is killed. Both f doors open. Two BLACK KIDS get out and look around with a manner that is if anything too casual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is faint muzak and loud air-conditioner hum. Glass  cases display donuts identified as GLAZED, JELLY, and FAN Fancies ooze yellow goo. The jelly on the jelly donuts is developing a crust of age. The glazed also look moth-eate One customer, a disheveled older man, sits at one of the  little formica tables staring into a coffee cup. Next to coffee is a brown paper bag from which a straw protrudes. Behind the counter is a middle-aged VIETNAMESE WOMAN in a neat white blouse. The two youths enter pulling out enormous handguns from  underneath their windbreakers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right Dragon Lady, give us all  the fuckin' money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman stares blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want that donut money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yao gin nyap!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man appears from the kitchen in back. He is a middle-ag Vietnamese gentleman in a crisply pressed khaki leisure s An ascot is knotted at his neck. He wears aviator eyeglas In his mouth smolders a half-burned-down filterless cigar This, we shall learn later, is THE GENERAL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay papa-san, we want that donut  money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we ain't fuckin' around, Mr. Hi- Ho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi-Ho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two youths look at her briefly. Nothing else is  forthcoming. The drunk looks up from his paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, this fuckin' thing, it ain't  complicated. You give us all the  fuckin money, you don't get shot in  the head, you make more donuts, get  more money. That's how it works,  see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General stares at him. As with his wife, none of it s to register; unlike his wife, he seems unperturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give us the money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is pointing the gun directly at the General's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You got three fuckin' seconds.  You understand one-two-three? I'm  gonna count one-two-three and then  shoot. Okay? Three secВ–- huh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General has swung his fist up to hook two fingers ins the youth's nostrils. His gun clatters to the floor. The  fingers are way, way up his nose. Only one knuckle shows each finger. The youth is staring cross-eyed at his own nose. His friend is also stupefied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very nasal) His fingers are way the fuck up my  nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GET... YA FINGAS... OUT... THE  MAN'S... NOSE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General still impassively sucks on his cigarette. The first youth is on the verge of tears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they're in my brain, man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOTHERFUCK!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raises his gun to start firing. As he does so the General uses his hook-hold on the other youth's nose to slam his head backwards, down into some  Fancies. The door opens and a customer walks in, a semi-elderly la with a cane. Youth #2, eyes rolling, wildly swings to cover the door,  then back to the General who has his friend's head presse into the Fancies, then uncertainly over to the Vietnamese woman who is loudly yelling at him in Vietnamese. Cigarette still dangling from his lower lip, the General  calmly plucks a pot of coffee from the coffee warmer and  tosses it into Youth #2's face. Youth #2 screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car is still pulsing hip-hop music. Youth #2 stumbles out of the Hi-Ho, hands covering his face and sinks to hi knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General now has the first youth's face pressed into t Fancies from behind. Without disturbing his smoking, the  General repeatedly kicks the youth in the ass. His wife, muttering irritably in Vietnamese, is wheeling water bucket and mop to where the floor is covered with  coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the CUT many voices are swelling in a song of worship. is a black Baptist church, and the music has great energy The white-robed choir finishes singing; a preacher takes podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you all remember that when  Moses came down the mountain, carrying  the word a God, come down that Sinai  peak, he caught those Israelites red- handed. What he catch 'em doin'? He  caught 'em worshipping a golden calf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouts of "That's right!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He caught 'em with their backs  turned on God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More shouts of "That's right!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He caught 'em worshipping a FALSE  God! A God of EARTHLY things! He  caught them Israelites in DECLINE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "He caught 'em!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Because backslidin' is DECLINE,  brothers and sisters! You hear talk  these days, and I know you've heard  this talk, you hear talk of DECLINE,  well all that means is we done turned  our back on God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "That's right!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...People say civilization doin'  this, civilization doin' that,  civilization in DECLINE! Well it  ain't no civilization! It ain't no  them! It's US, brothers and sisters!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Amen!" We are TRACKING among the congregants, disproportionately women, mostly of middle age and elderly, mostly wearing  elaborate go-to-church hats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It's what's in our hearts, each  and every one of us when we like  them Israelites! Slidin' awa-a-a-ay  down that Godly slope, slippin' and  slidin' toward the mire and muck a  the stinkhole of greed -- that's  DECLINE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "That's decline!" The CONTINUING TRACK brings us onto Mrs. Munson, wearing, like most of her peers, an oversized hat; hers is adorned with a great deal of plastic fruit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And what did Moses do when he saw  those declinin' backslidin' never- mindin' sinners?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "What he do?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Moses SMOTE those sinners in his  wrath yes he did!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Yes he did!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Y'all know what smote is! I smite!  You smite! He smites! We done smote!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "That's right!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...To smite is to go UPSIDE the head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Uh-huh!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Because sometimes, brothers and  sisters, that is the ONLY way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Yes it is!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...To smite is to reMIND! We got to  STOP that decline! And scramble back  UP to the face a the almighty Gyod!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Amen!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...'Stead a worshippin' that GOLDEN  calf, that earthly TRASH on that  GARBAGE island! That GARBAGE island  in that shadowland WAY outside the  Kingdom a God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Way outside!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That GARBAGE island where scavenger  birds feast on the bones a the  backslidin' damned!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Yes they do!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And so, let us pray...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a white clapboard country church. The preacher stan at the door chatting with the congregants filing out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You preach a wonderful sermon, Brother  Cleothus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why thank you, Sister Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man has a lot to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And every word of it the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-mm. Jesus well pleased with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deed he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh now ladies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased as he can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stout, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh now you gracious ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson is at the kitchen table. She folds a five dol bill into a sheet of paper, raising her voice as she does so:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a good sermon. That man has a  lot to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have CUT to the portrait of Othar over the mantel. He  does not answer. From the kitchen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Stout, too. It would've been a  comfort to you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson has stuffed the paper-enclosed bill into an  envelope, which she is now laboriously addressing to Bob  Jones University.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the choir was all in good voice.  Mm-mm-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Who could that--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat yowls and hisses.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. MUNSON HOUSE
dialogues.text: As Mrs. Munson swings open the door. G.H. Dorr stands on the stoop mournfully dry-washing his  hands and obsequiously ducking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Mrs. Munson, I do so hope  this is not an inopportune time for  our first practice--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your-- Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks back at the long black vintage Lincoln hearse pa at the curb behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...No no, no bereavement, though it  is so kind of you to enquire. No,  the hearse is simply a vehicle  commodious enough to accommodate all  of the members of our ensemble. And  of course our instruments, contrived  in an age ignorant of  miniaturization...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and gestures at the vehicle. At his sign, Gawain, the custodian, emerges from the driv side. Clark Pancake emerges from the front passenger side. The General, wearing a different but equally pressed khak suit and ascot, and with a smoking cigarette in his lips, emerges from a back door. Gawain goes to the back of the hearse and opens its hatch let out Lump Hudson, the football player. Lump helps unload five large and oddly shaped instrument  cases, each man taking one except for Lump himself, who  carries two. As the parade of losers and misfits winds it way up the walk:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Let me introduce you to my friends,  my colleagues, these devoted and  passionate musicians... This is Gawain  MacSam, our bassoonist...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain nods as he passes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...General Nguyen Pham Doc, viola da  gamba...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No smoking in this house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General tosses his cigarette away and bows stiffly as passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Clark Pancake -- a multi- instrumentalist, but with his  remarkable embosser Clark specializes  in wind instruments, and is especially  accomplished on the French horn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods, passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And, finally, Aloysius "Lump"  Hudson. Lump is our sackbuttist and --  thank you, Lump -- I see you've also  brought my fiddle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he hands Dorr the violin case:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your fiddle, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson sizes up the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't gonna make a racket, are  ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. Oh no no no no no. No, we  shall recuse ourselves to the basement  where we shall be -- I think here  the expression is uniquely  appropriate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives a sickly smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as quiet as the crypt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General stands stock still, his nose an inch away fro the earthen wall, studying it, squinting through the smok of the cigarette pinched between his lips. The rest of the men are opening their cases and taking ou the instruments. Gawain's case contains, however, not a  musical instrument but a boombox and several tapes. He lo one of the tapes into the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think, General? Present  any problems?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a beat the General turns away from the wall to give Dorr a look into which one might read anything, or nothin Gawain hits play on the boombox and the cellar is filled  with the fussy strains of baroque chamber music. Dorr nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Good then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spreads a map open on the sackbutt case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...All right, gentlemen, why don't  we all crowd around and go over the  plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The biggest feature on the map is a wavy, roughly north-s pair of lines: a river. A boat icon sits at one edge and  from it a dotted rectangle extends inland. Dorr taps at the boat icon with his fiddle bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This, gentlemen, is the Lady Luck,  gambling den, cash cow, Sodom of the  Mississippi delta -- and the focus  of our little exercise. Here is  Orchard Street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is tracing a street that parallels the dotted rectangl extending from the boat. The street is lined by small hou icons on either side; the bow comes to rest on one of tho icons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and here is the residence of Marva  Munson, the charming lady whom y'all  met moments ago. Gentlemen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bow taps emphasize:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You... are... here. Now. This  brings us to this square...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bow indicates it, and then withdraws. Dorr uses the bow as a swagger stick to punctuate as he b to pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Gentlemen, I believe you are all  aware that the Solons of the State  of Mississippi, to wit, its  legislature, have decreed that no  gaming establishment shall be erected  within its borders upon dry land.  They may, however, legally float  upon any watercourse defining a state  boundary. But while the gambling  activity itself is restricted to  riverboats, no such restriction  applies to the functions ancillary  to this cash besotted bidnis. The  casino's offices, locker rooms,  facilities to cook and clean, and  most importantly its counting houses- the reinforced, secret, and super  secure repositories of the lucre --  may all be situated... wherever.  Gawain -- where is wherever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say wha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr's smug smile fades. Testily:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. End of every shift pit boss brings  the cash down to the hold of the  ship in the locked cash box; once a  day all the cash boxes're moved to  the counting room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where is the counting room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh... in that square there.  Where you pointing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what, to flog a horse that if  not at this point dead is in mortal  danger of expirin', does the dotted  square represent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain hesitates, the question's obviousness suggesting t him some trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Offices. Underground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr's eyes close. A smile of feline contentment curls hi lips. He murmurs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Underground... Mmm... During the  casino's hours of operation the door  to the counting room is fiercely  guarded, and the door itself is of  redoubtable Pittsburgh steel; when  the casino is closed the entire  underground complex is locked up and  the armed guard retreats to the  casino's main entrance. There, then,  far from the guard, reposes the money,  cosseted behind a five-inch-thick  steel portal, yes, but the walls,  gentlemen, the walls of that room,  are but humble masonry, behind which  is only the soft loamy soil deposited  over the centuries by Ol' Man, the  meanderin' Mississip', as it fanned  its way back and forth across this  great alluvial plain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has pried a fistfull of dirt from the cellar wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crumbles it, letting it sift to the floor, and then,  pleased with himself, he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lump looks around, then hesitantly raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yes, Lump?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, uh... what does "cosseted"  mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again Dorr's smile fades. He does not dignify the  question with answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General here, whose curriculum  vitae compahends massive tunneling  experience thoo the soil of his native  French-Indochina, will direct our  little ol' tunnelin' operation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General acknowledges with a curt nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Clark Pancake, while a master of  none, is a jack of all those trades  corollary to our aim. He will be  doin' such fabricatin' and demolition  work as our little caper shall  require.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark acknowledges verbally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy to be on board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain is the proverbial "inside  man". He has managed to secure a  berth on the custodial staff of the  Lady Luck, thereby placin' himself  in a position to perform certain  chores whose precise nature needn't  detain us here, but whose performance  shall guide this expedition to its  happy conclusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya damn skippy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this brings us to Lump. To look  at Lump you might wonder, what  function could he possibly fill,  what specialized expertise could he  possibly offer, to our merry little  ol' band a miscreants. Well gentlemen,  in a project of such magnitude and  such risks, it is traditional --  nay, it is imperative -- to enlist  the services of a hooligan, a goon,  an ape, a physical brute, who will  be our security, our fist, our  batterin' ram. Lump is our blunt  instrument, and on all our behalfs I  wish him a warm Mississippi welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Professor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well gentlemen, here you are, men of  different backgrounds and differing  talents, men with, in fact only two  things in common: one, you all saw  fit to answer my little advertisement  in the Memphis Scimitar, and, two,  you are all going to be, in  consequence, very very incredibly  rich. Let us revel in our adventure,  gentlemen. Let us make beautiful  music together. And above all,  gentlemen, let us keep it to  ourselves. What we say in this root  cellar, let it stay in this root  cellar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no "I" in "team".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Lump has a very excellent point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music swells, supported now by a male chorus that has the spirited manliness of the Red Army choir. We

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men at work, tunneling. The cat sits on the cellar floor, head cocked, gazing at hole now opened in the wall. Lump, in a sleeveless undershirt, glistening with sweat,  wields a pickaxe at the forward point. At the mouth of the hole Clark Pancake shovels dirt into heavy plastic refuse bag held open by Gawain. G.H. Dorr sits on a camp chair, one hand idly waving time the music, reading an old and yellowed tome with half-gla perched midway down his nose. The General hops nimbly out of the tunnel and unzips and  steps out of his all-in-one to reveal, underneath, his ne pressed leisure suit and ascot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, Dorr stands at the head of the cellar stairs, look around the empty parlor. He gives a nod down the stairs a the men troop up past him, carrying sacks of earth. Over the mantelpiece, the eternal flame of the devotional candle almost animating his features, Othar seems to watc the men as they cross to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men load the earth into the hearse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are at the Mississippi bridge that we saw in the prolo to the movie, but now, in dead of night, deserted. The hearse is pulling up at the middle of the bridge and  dimming its lights. The men emerge; when they open the ba of the hearse to pull out the sacks, the cat bounds out t watch from a distance. We watch the men from HIGH, ANGLED DOWN along the masonry a tower that stands in the middle of the suspension bridg An ornamental gargoyle leers in the foreground. The garbage scow is approaching. We hear the low toot of horn as it nears the bridge. Lump is poised with the first sack hugged to his chest,  leaning over the railing. The nose of the barge enters below us. Lump releases the sack. We watch it drop dead away like a bomb from an airplane. It thuds distantly onto the barge. The next sack has been passed up to Lump and is released. The cat watches. Its orange eyes blink. Its pupils adjust

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PULL BACK shows that the cat is in fact back in the  basement. Its POV: continued tunneling. Back to the cat, watching, then turning its head at a noi At the head of the stairs, the cellar door is opening. A whistle from the General and Lump and Clark Pancake scr from the tunnel. They whip a curtain over its opening and all men grab up their instruments as Dorr, covering with cough, turns off the CD player. The General, his ever-present cigarette smoldering betwee his lips, tongue-and-lips it up and backwards so that it inside his mouth, which he now closes. Marva Munson is heavily and carefully descending the stai As the men come into view they are looking up at her, Lum holding his sackbutt but still glistening with sweat and  smeared with dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay, don't stop on account  of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lump looks around, saucer-eyed, then blows gamely into hi sackbutt. It sounds like goose farts until Dorr waves him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no, madam, we were about to take  a break anyway. The glissandi on  this particular piece are technically  very demanding and I think we would  all welcome a moment of relaxation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh. I just thought you might like  to see-what a you gotten up to, honey?  Why you sweatin' like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is directed at Lump, who looks down at his own sweat- stained undershirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man plays one bitch barrelful a  sackbutt. Ain't no one can blow the  tenor sackbutt like Lump, hoowee!  goes at that thing like it was a pu--  uh, like it was a woman! Goddamn! He--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cuffs him on the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mind! I don't want that kind of  talk in my home, even in the root  cellar. This is a Christian house,  boy, none of that hippity-hop  language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadly, Gawain is given to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAP! She slaps Gawain again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes it's the only way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He untenses after what seemed like the final blow, but -- WHAP! -- she slaps him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm tryin' to help you, son!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Better yaself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As well you should, ma'am. But Gawain  at times is so far transported by  his love of the music of the early  Renaissance as to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make no never-mind he's  transported!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr has her by the elbow and is ushering her back up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand your--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls her elbow away and sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been smokin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not, madam. I understand  your indignation. And I was offering  explanation, not excuse. I myself am  offended by those who cannot find  the proper words to express themselves  and have recourse to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain calls up the stairs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you be explainin' me, dawg!  You can't look into my mind, cape  man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr's tone is soothing as he shuts the door at the top o the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...A fiery lad! But then Youth is  fiery! A fact often remarked upon by  the poets of the Romantic era.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My youth I was in church, I wasn't  walkin' around fiery. Youth ain't no  excuse for nothin'! Well, anyway...  only came down to show you the fife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him a thick, roughly whittled piece of cane. Do holds it, looks at it dumbly. He is, for the first time t we have seen anyway, non-plussed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Othar's fife. He burned his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr tries to summon conversation as the two sit with the backs to the fireplace:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hm. I thought maybe bein' a musical  man you'd be interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I am indeed--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it himself and burned the holes.  Israelites called it a kalil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kalil, fife, same thing. You can  read about it in the Bible. Ain't  nothin' new under the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone these twenty years. He was some  kind of man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Othar's POV, slightly high, we see them both twist i their chairs to look up at the portrait. REVERSE of the portrait, LOW ANGLE. Othar looks down at u with what appears to be bemusement. Marva Munson and Dorr gaze up at the portrait for a motio beat. At length, Marva Munson sighs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Blowed the kalil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr's eyes remain on the picture as he inquires:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't suppose Othar ever turned  his hand -- or, uh, heh-heh-heh,  turned his lip -- to the shofar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prompted by her silence, he adds:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The ceremonial ram's horn, sounded  by the priests of the Hebrews?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know nothin' 'bout that.  Othar didn't study no shofar, to the  extent a my knowledge. The kalil was  good enough for my Othar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gazes at the portrait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Some kind of man.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND A SASHAYING ASS
dialogues.text: following a woman in a red dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey baby, don't be cruel. Jus' sneak  one little peek...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman looks back over her shoulder, smiling, as she  continues to walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Don't let this uniform fool ya--

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE PULLING TRACK
dialogues.text: leads Gawain MacSam, pushing his wheeled trash bin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need to be gamblin', honey,  you lookin' at a sure thing. They  call me Mr. 21, baby, 'cause that's  how I measure up. I am the original  black Jack, honey, accept no  substitutions. You can pull my lever  all day long, sweet mama, I ain't  never gonna come up lemons. That's  right, sugar, you can blow on my  dice any ol' time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gudge has his feet up on the desk and is filing his nails with an emery board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mr. Gudge, she had an ass that  could pull a bus. This lady was fine,  fine, dandy, divine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care how big her ass was,  MacSam. You're fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no fraternizing with  customers on the Lady Luck. Clean  out your locker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But GudgeВ–-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here. You're fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't fire me. I sue your ass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue me? For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue you for fuckin' punitive damages,  man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Punitive damages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya damn skippy. I know you firin' my  ass 'cause I'm black!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone on the custodial staff is  black, MacSam. Your replacement's  gonna be black. His replacement will  no doubt be black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' judge is gonna be black,  motherfucker, that's who gonna be  black! You gonna stand tall before  the man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are looking down past the distinctive pylon-mounted ye letters: WAFFLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band of miscreants is seated around a table with cups coffee. Dorr's wardrobe makes no concession to the inform of the setting; he still wears his cape and a black strin tie. His manner is more mournful even than usual:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my. Oh my my my my my. This is a  severe setback. I am distraught. I  am more than distraught, I am  devastated. Oh my, this is quite the  monkey-wrench heaved into the  meticulously engineered construct of  our little escapade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it fucks things up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am beside myself. I am at a positive  loss for words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still talkin' okay though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you all decided?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr's intensely mournful agitation is brought to bear up her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh madam, we must have waffles. We  must all have waffles forthwith!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hand in their menus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Oh we must think. We must all  have waffles and think, each and  every one of us to the very best of  his ability! Perhaps if you apologized  to the man and gave him flowers, or  perhaps a fruit basket, with a card  depicting a misty seascape and  inscribed with a sentiment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, man, it ain't about apologizin'!  He fired me 'cause I'm black!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't do that. You could sue him.  Open and shut case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not 1952.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man's a fuckin' bigot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, perhaps, surely, a  chocolate assortment has been known  to warm the heart of even the most  hardened misanthrope, especially if  it's a premium chocolate, imported,  say, from Switzerland, or the  Netherlands, or some other of the so- called "Low" countries be they Dutch  or Flemish or Walloon--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walloon my ass, the man ain't gonna  roll over for a fuckin' candy bar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid there's a setback on the  tunneling front too. We've run into  a pretty large rock, and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Rock!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All turn to look at the General. He continues to stare at spot in space. He slowly releases some inhaled cigarette  smoke, murmuring:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Very bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my my, it seems that the poet was  right: Troubles never singly come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we can get through the rock, no  worries there. Simplest thing in the  world. Why we blow right through it;  I've got a pyro license, we bore a  hole in the rock, pack in a little  plastique; igneous blows pretty good,  and we--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he gonna want a piece of the  action?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All turn to look at Lump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lump hesitates, looking at the inquiring faces that surro him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Igneous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A female Voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Clark. Am I ordering the prima  cord?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men look up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mountain, we were just talking  about that, and some plastique.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the men are staring at her, agog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The fuck is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mountain Girl. Mountain is  my right hand. She helps me with  ordnance. Helps me with damn near  everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You brought your bitch to the  waffle house?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is tension in the air. Dorr clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I confess myself to be puzzled as  well. I thought we all understood  that, so far as our little enterprise  is concerned, mum, as the saying  would have it, is the word--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. I understand that. But  this is Mountain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't keep secrets from Mountain.  That's not how you maintain a loving,  caring relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You brought your bitch to the  waffle house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Man brings his bitch to the waffle  house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you, I'll thank you to stop  referring to Mountain that way. She's  the other half of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody lookin' at me like I'm a  fuck-up, losin' that sorry-ass job,  and this motherfucker bring his bitch  to the waffle house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake lunges across the table, sending dishes clatterin to the floor as he grabs Gawain by the shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You son of a bitch punk! Shut your  goddamn mouth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes him vigorously and rears back to take a swing a him. Gawain draws a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come and get me motherfuck! Come on,  baby, let's get it on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mountain starts screaming. People look, aghast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other men pry Pancake and Gawain apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Gentlemen, this sort of behavior  does you no credit in the eyes of  your colleagues, or in those of the  other patrons of this waffle house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake grumbles as he composes himself and straighten hi clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Nobody talks to Mountain Girl  that way. She had an abusive family!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little punk. I got syrup on my safari  jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He embraces Mountain, who continues to sob quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I propose that we consider  the matter of this woman, Mountain  Water, to be--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mountain Girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so very sorry. I propose that  we consider this matter to be closed,  and we shall chose to trust her,  since we now have no choice, and  since she shall share only in Mr.  Pancake's portion of the booty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the shoulder of the quietly weeping Mountain Girl:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Wouldn't have it any other  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn right you won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up yours, punk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen! And the manner of disposing  of our igneous impediment is also  settled. That leaves only the question  of Gawain retrieving his job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't you just bribe the guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All turn to look at Lump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
