dialogues.text: Othar looks serenely down from his spot over the mantelpi Marva Munson knits; G.H. Dorr sits nodding over an ancien volume of half-forgotten lore, reading glasses perched mi down his nose. Curtains waft lazily in the summer night  breeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You just a readin' fool, ain't  you Mr. Dorr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes yes, I must confess, madam, that  often I feel more at home in these  ancient volumes than I do in the  hustle-bustle of our modern world.  To me, paradoxically, the literature  of the so-called "dead tongues" has  more currency than this mornin's  newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In these books...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He removes his glasses and lazily twirls them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...In these volumes, there is the  accum'lated wisdom a mankind which  succours me when the day is hard or  the night lonely and long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wisdom of mankind, what about the  wisdom of the Lord?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, the Good Book, mm. I have  found reward in its pages. But for  me there are other good books as  well; the heavy volumes of Antiquity,  freighted with the insights of Man's  glorious age. And then of course I  love, love, love the works of Mr. Ed  G'Allan Poe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who he is. Kinda creepy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, madam, noooo. Not of this  world, true; he lived in a dream, an  ancient dream...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr himself is lost in a dream:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Helen, they beauty is to me Like  those Nicean barks a yore That gently,  o'er a perfumed sea, The weary,  wayworn wanderer bore To his own  native shore... "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was Helen? She wasn't a loose  woman, was she? Some kinda whore a  Babylon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr is still lost:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One doesn't know who Helen was, though  I picture her as bein' very, very  extremely... pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes to himself, focuses on Mrs. Munson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Miz Munson, I was tryin' to think  of some way of expressin' my gratitude  to you for takin' in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...this weary, wayworn wanderer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Professor takes a small ticket envelope from where it had served as bookmark, and hands it across.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It's just a modest little ol'  present, why it's practically nothing  at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaming, she takes two tickets out of the envelope and  inspects them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Mr. Dorr, why you are such a  gallant man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no madam, I blush. I melt. No, I  just happened to hear of this gospel  concert tomorrow night, The Mighty  Mighty Clouds of Joy, and I thought  you and a friend from church,  perhaps...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othar loved that music... Yes, I got  a widow-lady friend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The concert is up in Memphis, but I  have arranged for a car service to  transport you thither and, needless  to say, back home at the concert's  termination. My friends and I will  be rehearsing here tomorrow evening  so you needn't worry about the  security of your charming little old  house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. MUNSON HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson swings the door open to Sheriff Wyner. His sq car is parked at the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Wyner, how you doin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Professor's eyes widen with concern as he hears the  voices, off:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evenin', Miz Munson, I just came  by...

dialogues.speaker: I/E. MUNSON HOUSE
dialogues.text: The sheriff is tipping his hat and already backing away,  trying to make his visit brief:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to let you know I had a word with  WeeMack. He says he gonna comply  with your request, keep the music  down and neighborly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He calls from the bottom of the stoop:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you have a pleasant evening now,  and just let us know--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on there, Sheriff, somebody I  want you to meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, I'm a little pressed for time--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, you chasin' a gang of bank  robbers? Get on in here say hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Voices approach:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...We was just havin' tea, talkin'  about Othar--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two enter and Mrs. Munson stops short, looking. The living room is empty. Even the Professor's teacup is  gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hm... Bussed his own dishes. You  can always tell a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheriff, hat in hand, gazes about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone was here, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hm, with me'n Othar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again, he tries to excuse himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I'll catch him next  time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on up to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and the two look in. The neatly made bed next to the small, barren dresser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm, he's neat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very neat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably went down to the cellar to  play with his friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, I really have to...

dialogues.speaker: UNDER THE BED
dialogues.text: Top-teased by a dust ruffle in the foreground, we see Mrs Munson's heavy orthopedic shoes turning to pass Sheriff  Wyner's shiny black boots.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: shows Dorr, cheek pressed to the floor, his teacup and sa under the bed with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...be gettin' back...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO NORMAL PERSPECTIVE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson is about to go out the door but notices somet A corner of the Professor's cape, protruding from under t end of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO DORR
dialogues.text: fearfully watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heavy orthopedic shoes approach, and then, with loud Mogul sounds of effort, Mrs. Munson's hands and knees hit the floor. Her head drops in to view to peer in, her own cheek again the floorboards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What the... Why, Professor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the Sheriff watching and his HIGH POV of Mrs. Muns enormous ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What you doin' havin' tea down  there?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr makes silent hand waves to disavow his own presence. Mrs. Munson roars with laughter. With difficulty she pushes herself back upright, still  laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Land of Goshen! Get out from under  there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miz Munson, my pager just went off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why of all the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff is already backing down the stairs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Fraid I gotta respond...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the front door and calls up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'll try to meet your friend some  other time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr shimmies out from under the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that was very... refreshing...  As you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets to his feet, slaps dust from the front of his pan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we academics are inordinately  fond of wedgin' ourselves into  confined spaces. At Yale the students  will see how many of their number  they can enclose in a telephone booth;  Harvard, a broom closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why I never!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was the goldfish-swallowin'  craze, of course, a different but  related phenomenon... Ahem... I hope  I didn't spill any tea...

dialogues.speaker: A BOX OF CHOCOLATES
dialogues.text: The box is being pulled open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shows Gawain in Mr. Gudge's office as Gudge, behind the d looks at the gift-wrapped box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just my way of sayin', well,  goddamnit, I don't know what it's  like walkin' in your shoes, bein'  all tightass and all, and you don't  know what it's like to walk in my  shoes, but, well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gudge is opening a card that was inside the box. Its flor front says in gold script, "I'm Sorry... If I hurt your  feelings... "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You know, there's the custodian,  and then there's the man inside the  custodian, y'understand what I'm  sayin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gudge opens the card. Inside is a hundred-dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and that man has needs, dig, and  I guess those needs, Mr. Gudge, which  they usually involve women with big  asses, well those motherfuckin' needs  sometimes well up over the custodian  like the motherfuckin' Johnstown  Flood. But my point is it ain't gonna  happen again. Not if it's humanly  possible...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gudge reads the card, flips it over to look at its back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Jesus, if you'd seen the ass on  that girl, Mr. Gudge, you'd a wanted  her sitting on your face too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're all human.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya damn skippy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This apology buys you a one-week  probationary period. Stay away from  the customers, MacSam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake is on his stomach, wearing goggles, boring a hole into a rock face with a power drill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the whine of the drill faintly here, all but cove by the sound of the chamber music on the boom box. The other men sit around. Dorr gives a casual glance at h watch as the whine subsides. Pancake emerges from the tunnel covered with grime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drill bit's getting awfully hot.  Gawain, maybe you could fill a hudson  sprayer and spritz it down while I  drill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, man, I ain't your house  nigger. I'm the inside man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, are you gonna have a bug up  your ass for the rest of the time we  work together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get the sprayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no, me and this gentleman here  have to get square. Let me tell you  something, MacSam. You wanna know  something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna know shit from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake leans against the wall and pushes his goggles up his forehead, leaving raccoon eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna tell you how I came down  to Mississippi. Wasn't born here,  you know. I'm from Scranton,  Pennsylvania...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abruptly, he stares off into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Nnnff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake's eyes regain their focus:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Scranton, Pennsylvania. Came down  here in 1964. Greyhound Bus. With  the Freedom Riders. You know who the  Freedom Riders were, MacSam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a shit who they were.  Just tell me when they gonna leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Freedom Riders, my fine young  man, were a group of concerned  liberals from up North -- whites,  Negros, and yes, Jewish people --  all working together, just like we  are here. Concerned citizens who  came down here so that local black  people could have their civil  liberties. So that people like you  could have the vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All look at Pancake. Quiet, except for the delicate chamb music. Gawain's tone softens:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You know what, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't vote. So fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake darkens:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you fucking--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the bus you rode in on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He peels off his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Let's step outside, MacSam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock on the cellar door. The men freeze  momentarily, then scramble for their instruments. The Gen flips his cigarette backwards into his mouth. Dorr turns off the boom box, then calls:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, madam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Mrs. Munson comes down the stairs, hol a large plate covered by a checked napkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend Mrs. Funthes is here so  I'm about to go on out. I just wanted  to leave y'all with some cinnamon  cookies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the napkin off and carries the plate from perso to person; each obediently takes a cookie with a murmured "Thank you, ma'am."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Y'all sound pretty good. It'd be  nice if you'd come by the church  some day, give us a recital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr takes her by the arm and escorts her back to the sta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh madam, you are too kind. Our music,  however, is -- how shall I put it? --  rather Roman in its outlook; many of  our pieces were commissioned by the  Holy See.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see all right, but we don't  make a big whoop-dee-do about  denominations; everybody welcome at  our church. We've had Methodists  come in. Episcopals. Even had a Jew  come in once with a guitar back in  the sixties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed. Excuse me, one moment, ma'am,  and I shall see you off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have reached the top of the stairs and the Professor ushers her out but stays behind himself. He turns to addr the rest of the men below:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...If you gentlemen can labor  harmoniously in the course of my  absence, then perhaps upon my return  we shall be prepared to explode that  vexin' ol' piece a igneous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the motherfuckin' piece of  igneous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Professor emerges from the cellar. Mrs. Munson awaits with her friend who is likewise togged out in fancy Sunda dress and carrying a shiny black purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor, this is Rosalie Funthes,  Rosalie, Professor G.H. Dorr, Ph.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my, that's an awful lot of letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well of course in my youth I was  simply known as Goldthwait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake is taking the boom box off the table to clear som space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, safety meeting, let's  listen up. General, could you hand  me the prima cord and the compound  there. Before we set the charge we'll  run through our procedure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various paraphernalia are laid out on the table. The cat sits in a corner of the cellar, watching carefull and, it seems, listening attentively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I have earplugs for whoever wants  them. Just wedge them in your ears.  Now here we have -- not yet, Lump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lump stops putting in his earplugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Now. Prima cord. Gelatinite. C4.  Time comes, we pack the hole in the  rock with the C4 and insert two leads.  A...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds up one lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds up the other lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Charge comes from a battery that  is inside this plunger. Ordinary  auto battery, you can pick it up at  Sears, easiest thing in the world...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black town car idles at the curb. Dorr is just escortin the two ladies out the front door and down the stoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember my father telling me --  and it is one of the few memories I  retain of the man, from one of his  visits home, and how I do cherish it --  he said, "Goldthwait, you are not  formed as other little boys."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He a man of learnin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G.H. number two was self-educated;  he had no career, as such, though  the state recognized the breadth of  his readin' by making him librarian  at the state nervous hospital in  Meridian, where he was a distinguished  inmate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake sets down the two electrical leads and picks up a hammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the same procedure we will  be using when we collapse the tunnel  after entering the casino vault and  returning to the root cellar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks pointedly at Gawain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This is for your own protection,  so pay close attention. Once these  materials are combined only the  professionals may handle them. That  means me, or the General. Separately  they are harmless-completely inert.  Why, you could light this stuff on  fire, hit it with a hammer--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swings the hammer down onto the plastique--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and there is the dull thud of an explosion and the hous windows rattle in their frames. The Professor, at the open door of the car into which the two ladies have just sat, looks up at the house, as do th ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What in the name of heaven was  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr stares at the house, appalled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... quite sure... that there is...  no cause for alarm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He struggles for self-possession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Why, I'm not even absolutely  certain that I heard anything at  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't hear anything?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, something, perhaps, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marva Munson starts to get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...nothing that need discompose us,  was the sense I was trying to  convey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He urges her back into her seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Miz Munson, I will not have you  missing your musical recital. Why,  you go ahead now. Miz Funthes, you  as well, I beg of you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is backing up the walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I shall call the gas company, or  the water company, or whatever  subterranean utility is implicated  in this little... occurrence... I  shall see to the matter... as only a  highly educated classicist could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the door now, he gives the two women peering out the c window a smiling but vigorous wave away, which they do no heed, and then he enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is filled with smoke. Othar, slightly askew over the mantel, looks a little huf We hear clomping and screaming on the cellar stairs. Lump bursts out, shrieking:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blood, Professor! Oh my God! Blood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General comes bounding up the stairs like a panther, cigarette burning in his lips. He lands catlike in the li room, glides to the blubbering Lump, grabs one shoulder f with one hand, and with the other slaps him sharply, once forehand, once backhand. Lump stares at him, shocked, his blubbering cut short. More noise is coming from the stairs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...why, it's nothing to make a fuss  about. Perfectly all right... happens  all the time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You gotta go find it, dipshit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake emerges from the stairwell, his hair singed, his  face and the front of his jumpsuit darkened by the blast. is clutching one hand with the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...No, no. Really, I'm perfectly all  right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain has ascended just behind to hector him over his  shoulder:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectly all right? You just blew  your fucking finger off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well get back down there and find  it, man! I ain't pickin' up your  goddamn finger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gather there was a premature  detonation--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can sew that shit back on, jack!  Like that guy his wife cut his dick  off! Just sewed that motherfucker  back on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Simplest thing in the  world. Microsurgery--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saw that motherfucker in a porno!  Thing still works!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake is pale from loss of blood and his pontifications lack full conviction:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, they have remarkable abilities  in the, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet. The two women sit in the idling car, looking at the house From the house there is very muted bellowing. Still looking toward the house, Mrs. Munson offers a word explanation to her friend:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They using the house to practice  music a the rococo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm-hm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat, with a human finger in its mouth, sidles cautiou to one side, warily eying someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General, pluming cigarette in his mouth, tensed arms  extended outwards, sidles cautiously to cut him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I propose that we get our fallen  comrade to the hospital, and the  General shall follow when he manages  to recover the severed digit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what all the fuss is  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat jumps. The General leaps to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two women looking. The front door of the house opens. Lump, the Professor, a Gawain emerge, escorting Pancake. Just before Gawain fini closing the door the cat slips out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PICKLES!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is yanked fully open and the General races out a the cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You catch Pickles now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat races across the lawn and, with no break in strid up his favorite tree. The General follows and, also without breaking stride,  clambers up the tree after it. Tree limbs shake with activity hidden by the leaves. We h the hiss of the cat. The men are bundling Pancake into the hearse. Dorr calls the women before climbing in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is perfectly in order, but  we need medical attention for Mr.  Pancake who, during the disturbance,  pinched his finger in a valve of the  sackbutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat leaps out of the tree and runs away down the road

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You let the cat out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General leaps out of the tree to land catlike on the  street, arms tensed, casts a look both ways, and then pur the animal down the road. We hear the retreating padding  footsteps of all six feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General is even now exercising  every effort to retrieve your  mischievous little pet. Please go,  go and enjoy your concert, and we  shall see you later in the evening.  Au revoir, mes dames!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new day. The garbage scow chugs down the mighty Mississ It toots its horn.

dialogues.speaker: SCHEMATIC MAP
dialogues.text: It shows the underground complex and, stretching towards in a line drawn with a blunt pencil, is the tunnel. It is now almost to the vault. A violin bow enters to tap at the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite our little setback we find  ourselves on schedule to penetrate  the vault...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bow taps at the vault outline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...here, this afternoon, having  successfully blasted that little ol'  rock to pieces during Miz Munson's  choir practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The violin bow withdraws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Clark, perhaps you can run us  through the game plan for what remains  of our tunnelin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bandaged hand enters frame and a finger-stump points at the end of the penciled line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Why, it's child's play  now, easiest thing in the world.  Only a couple of feet separate us  from the vault...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are clustered around the map, spread out on the  sackbutt case in the cellar. Clark continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Just the usual spadework until we  hit the masonry of the vault, and  then we drill through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And will you be able to wield the  drill with your maimed extremity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I should think so, it's only one  finger. Inhibits me in doing finer  work, of course. I'll always have to  live with that... Ahem. Maybe, and  I'm just thinking out loud here,  maybe since, as you say, it will  present problems later...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Clark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe -- and this is something  I've talked over with Mountain Girl,  and she agrees with me, so it's not  just one person's opinion -- maybe I  should get a little extra compensation  for the accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long, stony silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Somewhat larger share. Why, if  this were any other line of work I'd  be getting workmen's comp, wouldn't  I? Might even have a pretty good  lawsuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna sue yaself for blowin' off  your finger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that is simply asinine--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes but you see, Clark, this is not  what you just called "some other  line of work."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if it were--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a criminal enterprise, not  to put too fine a point on it,  entailin' all manner a risks not  involved in honest labor. Governmental  regulations an' civic safeguards  cannot be assumed to apply to  antisocial pursuits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but he lost his finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't give a shit! Man can blow  his own dick off, don't make no  nevermind to us! We don't gotta pay  the man for goin' around blowin' off  body parts! Getcha head outcha ass,  man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that in this instance Gawain  has a very excellent point. I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No extra share!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All stop and stare at the General. Clark grumbles:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, okay, majority rules, like I  say, it was just a trial balloon.  Hand's not so bad really, I even get  some phantom feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pull on your prick you get phantom  feeling. Greedy motherfuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that that matter is settled, let  us synchronize our watches before  Gawain reports to work. In... twenty  seconds... it will be twelve-sixteen  exactly... fifteen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be twelve-fifteen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, in fifteen seconds -- now eleven  seconds -- it will be twelve- sixteen... eight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six... five -- yes, Lump?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the weathered doorway to the main entrance of the L Luck. A hand enters to rap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, dickwad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A low, chesty chuckle. The door swings open and Gawain en

dialogues.speaker: RUMBLING WHEELS ON NUBBY FLOOR
dialogues.text: A garbage bin is being wheeled across the empty casino fl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain is wheeling it. He is approaching the tunnel to th corporate annex.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE WHEELS
dialogues.text: As they roll down the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud singing at the cut. We are looking at Mrs. Munson in the middle of the choir, holding forth in song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain leans back against the wall next to the vault door arms folded across his chest. Faintly, from inside the va we hear the whine of a power tool. Gawain leans over and  punches the button on boom box that hangs from the rollin garbage bin. The hallway pulses with "I Left My Wallet In Segundo."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More singing, Mrs. Munson and the rest of the choir now  clapping as they sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The power-tool whine is louder here. We are looking at a  patch of wall. After a beat, and with a loud rev as resistance gives way drill bit emerges from the wall, spitting out bits of the masonry. The drill withdraws. After a beat, hammer blows. The chunk of masonry begins to buckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General opens the door, still somehow immaculately  groomed. Gawain enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gospel number rising to climax, supported by the orga and the rest of the congregation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark and Lump, covered in dirt and plaster dust, have st stuffing bundled bills and small sacks into large garbage bags. An irregular hole, about three feet across, gapes i the far wall. Gawain punches off the boombox, looking at all the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ain't that somethin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark suddenly freezes in the act of collecting money. He straightens slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hnnnn. Arrunggggh! Rnffff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands stock still, wincing, gazing off into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mmmmnggh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whispers hoarsely, urgently:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...IBS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other men look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Say what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IBS! Irritable Bowel Syndrome! Is  there a men's room down here?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh man, you shouldn't be using the  men's room--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or a lady's room! IBS! Quickly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shoulda shit back in the house,  man! We don't want Elron finding you  in the goddamn crapper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark's voice is still hoarse. He does small knee bends o urgency:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No choice! Quickly! It's a medical  condition!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are disgusting, man. All right,  follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are CLOSE ON Gawain peering anxiously to one side. He turns and peers the other way. We hear a toilet flush and, after a beat, Clark emerges f the men's room door next to which Gawain stands. His mann is now completely relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feel thirty pounds lighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start walking back to the vault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Thank you for being so  understanding. Not everyone is, of  course, which is why the biggest  challenge of IBS is educating the  public. Afflicts over two million  people yet most of us have never  heard of it. And it strikes without  regard to age, gender or race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh fuck, man, I don't wanna know  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the kind of attitude we're  fighting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well maybe you should sign me up,  man, 'cause you startin' to irritate  my bowel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The choir finishes a number and sits -- all except for Ma Munson, who unties the knot on her robe at the nape of he neck, slips it off and, with murmured goodbyes, slips awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the two men enter Clark is still holding forth:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I guess I never told you, that's  how Mountain Girl and I met. They  had an IBS Weekend at Grossinger's,  in the Catskills. Of course the  tourist business up there has  suffered, with the demise of the  Borscht Belt. So they have different  promotions, mixers, so on. This was  a weekend for Irritable Bowel singles  to meet and support each other and  share stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I don't wanna hear a single one  a them stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, some of them are very--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not one fuckin' story! You one fucked- up motherfucker! You--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop short, looking: The General and Lump are standing in the middle of the fl stock still, each clutching a bag of money, staring up at the same corner of the ceiling. Lump turns to Clark and Gawain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, lookit that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain and Clark join them in the middle of the vault and look up at the corner of the ceiling. A small video camera, aimed squarely at the four men.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE CAMERA
dialogues.text: Black-and-white video, very WIDE ANGLE HIGH SHOT, of the  four motionless men below goggling up at the lens. Smoke  plumes from the General's cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh. Looks like an Ikegami.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slips on his reading glasses as he gets a leg up on a  shelf just below the camera and hoists himself. He peers at the lens.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE LENS
dialogues.text: Clark looming into EXTREME CLOSE SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Oh yeah. Mm-hm. I'm not sure  whether it's broadcasting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is fingering the back of the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hard wire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down below, Gawain looks at the wire snaking along the se of wall and ceiling. At the opposite corner it travels do the joint of the two walls. He traces its path down and then across one wall at chair rail height towards the door. The other men follow in an  anxious herd as he traces one finger along it. Just before reaching the vault door the wire goes through the wall in a hole finished off with a grommet. Gawain go out the vault door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and picks up the line where it emerges on the other si travels down to the joint of wall and floor, and then  continues along the floor. Gawain follows it and the othe men continue to follow him. He traces it anxiously down the hall in a hunched lope. T other men scuttle behind into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wire winds around into the room, back up to chair-rai height, along one wall, behind some cabinetry which Gawai hurries past to find it again on the far side, and then d to a video recorder. It is not, however, hooked up to the video recorder: its  pronged end swings loose just by where it would be plugge in. Inside the video recorder is a casette, which Gawain ejec The men crowd to look over his shoulder as he examines it "Shevann's Schvanz". There is a pile of other videos by the monitor: "Charlayn and the Chocolate Factory," "Big Dick Blaque's Big Night  Out," "Lemme Tell Ya 'Bout Black Chicks," "Anus & And Just next to the pile is an old bowl of Kocoa Krispies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General climbs into the tunnel with a garbage bagful money, followed by Lump, likewise encumbered. Lump hands  back out a satchel to Gawain, who sets it on the vault fl by the hole. From the way he handles it, it is quite heav Pancake, also with a bag of money, is getting ready to cl in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I didn't choose to have IBS--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lump hands Gawain a smaller, lighter satchel which he lik sets on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no cure, you know. Only  control. Lifelong condition. Not  complaining, just fact. And I did  meet Mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grab your bag and get in that fucking  hole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson is leaving, with singing still audible from t service that continues inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are looking from inside the tunnel towards its mouth,  where the Professor stoops slightly to peer in, anxiously dry-washing his hands. A REVERSE shows the hunched-over men scuttling along the  tunnel towards us, holding large garbage sacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome back, gentlemen, mission  accomplished I see. I am so very  very delighted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives a hand down to each man as he exits the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Congratulations. Congratulations.  I have some cold duck on ice for the  occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we could have something to  drink, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain, left behind, is muttering to himself as he uses a trowel and other instruments from his satchel to patch up the hole at his end of the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motherfucker can't stop talking,  can't stop shitting. Motherfucker  tell everyone about his motherfuckin'  asshole. No one gives a shit about  his asshole. Nobody interested in  another man's asshole. Or his bitch's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson is letting herself in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are sitting around the table, champagne glasses  raised. On the table sits the money, stacked in orderly p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, to we few. We who have  shared each other's company, each  other's care, each other's joy, and  who now reap the fruits of our  communal effits, shoulder to shoulder,  from each accordin' to his abilities  so forth whatnot. We have had our  little diffences along the way, it's  true, but I like to think they have  only made us value one another the  more, each coming to understand and  appreciate the other's unique  qualities, potencies, and, yes,  foibles. I suggest that we shall  look back upon this caper one day,  one distant day, grandchildren dandled  upon our knee, and perhaps a tear  will form, and we shall say, Well,  with wit, and grit, and no small  amount of courage, we accomplished  something on that day, a feat of  derring-do, an enterprise not ignoble --  we, merry band, unbound by the  constraints of society and the  prejudices of the common ruck, we  happy few. Gentlemen -- to us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They clink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstairs Mrs. Munson runs water into a teapot, humming to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having finished patching, Gawain starts painting. He turn on his boombox, and out comes the big bassy "I Left My Wa in El Segundo."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men, having drunk deep, are setting down their glasse Pancake looks at his watch with some concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charge should've gone off already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The charge to collapse the tunnel. I  set it for eight minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that time, and more, has most  certainly elapsed.

dialogues.speaker: FROM INSIDE THE TUNNEL
dialogues.text: Looking toward the mouth. The men stoop over and peek  fearfully in. They again stand upright. A silence. Dorr clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need not remind you of the  importance of obliterating any trace  of a connection between the vault  and this house. It was of the essence  of this plan that it should appear  that the money had simply vanished.  Without a trace. Spirited away, as  it were, by ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conundrum of the undisturbed yet  empty vault, the unsolvable riddle  of the sealed yet violated sanctum,  is of the utmost importance not only  to make our caper innelectually  satisfying. It is also exigent as a  matter of practical fact: I remind  you that if a tunnel is ever found  leading to this house, this house's  owner knows all of your names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She certainly does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therefore -- to draw the unavoidable  conclusion -- someone shall have to  reenter the tunnel to reset that  charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake, hunched over, scurries along the tunnel. He reac the remnants of a large rock, where the tunnel grows smal He drops to crawl position and elbows his way forward,  toolbelt clanking along. We are getting closer and closer to a muffled but thuddin bassy "I Left My Wallet in El Segundo."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music loudly present at the cut. Gawain takes a handh blowdryer out of his satchel and flips it on, directing i at the fresh paint on the wall whose repairs are now  invisible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music once again muffled. Pancake has reached a little LE displaying timer with leads trailing off of it. He grabs it, puts on his reading glasses, squints. The display shows: TIME REMAINING: 00:12. The colons in the display rhythmically blink, but the num does not advance. For some reason, stuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches to his tool belt, pulls out his Leatherman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson is setting places at a large table. There are about a dozen place settings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake now has a mini-mag light clenched between his tee aimed down at the timer. He opens the phillips head on hi Leatherman but abruptly stops and stares off into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nnnnrungh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is squinting with pain. The muffled hip-hop song is beginning to recede.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain is wheeling his garbage cart out the door. The vau is completely empty but looks completely undisturbed. He closes the heavy vault door behind him, leaving quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet here as well, now. Pancake's moan trails off to not He relaxes. The moment, whatever it was, has passed. He looks back down at the unit, flicks it with his finger and it emits a soft beep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He squints at the back of the unit. As it beeps again, he turns the unit over to look at its  face. The readout now says: 00:10. As he watches, peering down through the bottom of his gla it continues to advance with a beep as each second slips 9... 8...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What the--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes widen and he frantically shakes the unit. It  continues beeping. He briefly and sloppily tries to fit t phillips head into one of the four screws on the back of unit but immediately gives up and starts a panicked wrigg back up the tunnel, whimpering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain is wheeling his garbage cart past Elron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson is placing the last piece of silverware, just so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake is in full panicked awkward flight as--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --BOOM! We CUT TO the cellar and Pancake is shot out the  tunnel like a human cannonball, trailing a comet-tail of  dirt, dust, and debris that wafts what were neatly stacke bills up into the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The portrait of Othar jostles back to square. He now look little angry. The cat arches her back, emitting a startled yowl. Mrs. Munson stands, frozen, then looks slowly around, try to assimilate what has just happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain and Elron are staring at each other, frozen, also  reacting to what just happened. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You just fart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heh-heh-heh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson is looking at the cellar door. Dust drifts ou from under it. She takes a slow step towards it. Another step. She opens the door. There is no visibility in the cellar due to swirling clay dust. She takes one step down the stairs, waving at the air in  front of her face. Paper money wafts in and out of the dust. We hear Voices:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectly all right. Not a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well there sure as shit ain't no  tunnel left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clearing dust reveals the caped Professor anxiously  dancing from foot to foot, gathering money out of the air As he reaches up to grab a bill that has him facing up in Mrs. Munson's direction, he freezes. His POV reveals her through dissipating dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor, I'm surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long beat, through which all stare at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Properly speaking, madam, we have  been surprised; you are taken aback.  Though I acknowledge that the sense  you intend is gaining currency through  increasing use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Further dissipation of the dust reveals how much money th is, settling now to cover the floor of the cellar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You have returned from your  devotions betimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the ring of the doorbell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hadda fix tea. I wanna talk to  you, Professor, don't you be leavin'.  And don't make any more noise! And  you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She points at the General who, in the excitement, has  neglected to hide his ever-present cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I told you, I don't want any  smokin' in here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She clomps upstairs and shuts the cellar door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PULL HER towards the front door, angry and lost in tho Her look softens somewhat as she opens the door. It is a chattering infestation of hens: all of her friend from church push in wearing church dresses and elaborate  hats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are still frozen looking up toward the door. The  muted cackle of church ladies. The men gradually unfreeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She saw everything. She saw our  hole...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to Dorr, near tears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...She saw our hole, Professor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr rubs his hands anxiously, thinking:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, first, my dear boy, we follow  the General's example...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General remains staring up at the door, frozen but fo the smoke pluming from the cigarette in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and refrain from panic. Secondly,  we cooly, calmly, collectedly think...  think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gaze of all the men drifts back up to the cellar door and we look down at them, gazing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chattering ladies are gathered at the table, Mrs. Mun pouring them tea. The cellar door creaks noisily -- one might almost say  gothically -- ajar, and the Professor peers out with an  ingratiating smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hsst... Madam...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chattering abates and the ladies all look at him. His smile broadens into ghastliness and he crooks a finger to Mrs. Munson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mrs. Munson, if I might have a  word...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get back down those stairs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assure you I shall be--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush! Down those stairs! We havin'  tea now! I be down shortly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods meekly and retreats, easing the door creakily shu The ladies look inquisitively at Mrs. Munson as his foots are heard descending the stair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He's the tenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Professor rejoins the still staring and silent gro The money has been picked up and is once again in stacks  upon the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shall be down shortly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explaining, he indicates upstairs with a jerk of the head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Tea. Dainties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men nod, murmuring. The cellar door squeaks open. There is the clomp of caref footsteps on the stair. Using only tongue and teeth, the General flips his smokin cigarette inwards into his mouth and gives Mrs. Munson hi usual deadpan look. She halts halfway down the stairs, still wearing an apron and holding a spatula.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you boys been up  to but I wasn't born yesterday and I  know mischief when I see it. Now I  want an explanation, but first I  want you boys to get your fannies up  here with y'alls period instruments.  I been tellin' the ladies about your  music and they wanna hear you play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to head back up the stairs but abruptly stops t turn and give the General a hard look which he innocently returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hmph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns again and clomps back up the stairs. The General opens his mouth and, again without using his  hands, restores his cigarette to its usual place on his l lip. Lump is fretful:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Lump?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't really play the buttsack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cellar door opens and the men troop out, G.H. Dorr le and the other men following rather sheepishly behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame -- or rather, mesdames -- you  will have to accept our apologies  for failing to perform since, as you  see, we are shorthanded. Gawain is  still at work and we could no more  play with one part tacit than a horse  could canter shy one leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I could offer as a poor but  ready substitute a brief poetic  recital. Though I don't pretend to  great oratorical skills, I will  happily present, with your ladies'  permission, verse from the unquiet  mind of Mr. Ed G'Allan Poe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lump, Pancake, and the General sit and awkwardly accept d teacups. The Professor rises, spreads his hand, and pronounces:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..."Ladies, thy beauty is to me Like  those Nicean barks of yore..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UPS of the various ladies, some sipping tea or slow munching biscuits, but all eyes glued to the declaiming m in the cape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "That gently, o'er a perfumed sea  The weary, wayworn wanderer bore To  his own native shore... "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murmuring Voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slurp of tea from another quarter. Dorr bears on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "On desperate seas long wont to roam,  Thy hyacinth hair, thy classic face,  Thy Naiad airs have brought me home  To the glory that was Greece And the  grandeur that was Rome... "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long silence. Then, scattered:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-mm. Glory hallelujah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lady holding a teacup turns to the General:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was soooome poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You know any?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the front door opening and Gawain enters, still  wearing his Lady Luck custodial uniform. He looks. His POV: church ladies with teacups and his comrades seat among them, also holding teacups and scones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all been celebratin'?.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bustling and chattering ladies are just finishing lea Mrs. Munson is seeing them off at the door. Evening is  gathering, and we hear the lonely toot of the distant gar scow. The men as well stand by the door and, affecting good che wave off the departing ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, ladies. We had such a  pleasant time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson closes the door and her manner instantly dark

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I wanna know what's goin' on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes indeed, and the thirst for  knowledge is a very commendable thing.  Though in this instance, I believe  when you hear the explanation, you  will laugh riotously, slappin' your  knee and perhaps even wipin' away a  giddy tear, relieved of your former  concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see Lump here is an enthusiastic  collector of Indian arrowheads and,  having found one simply lying on  your cellar floor, a particularly  rare artifact of the Natchez tribe,  he enlisted us in an all-out effort  to sift through the subsoil in search  of others. Well, in doing so, we  apparently hit a motherlode of natural  gas -- I myself became acutely aware  of the smell of "rotten eggs" -- and  it was at just this unfortunate moment  that the General here violated one  of the cardinal rules of this house  and lit himself a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General stiffly bows:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Professor, nodding, smiling, and dry-washing his hand continues to look at Mrs. Munson, though his story,  apparently, has ended. She returns his ingratiating look with a stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What about all that money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr's smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Ah. The money. The money is...  Mr. Pancake's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He only just re-mortgaged his house  in order to pay for the procedure  that will correct the wandering eye  of his common-law wife, Mountain  Water, who suffers from astygmia and  strabismus and a general curdling of  the vitreous jelly. Mr. Pancake  however is an ardent foe of the  federal reserve and is in fact one  of those eccentrics about whom one  occasionally reads, hoarding his  entire life savings either under the  proverbial mattress or, as in Mr.  Pancake's case, in a Hefty bag that  is his constant companion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under her stare, he elaborates:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Steel Sack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't trust the banks. Never have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She thinks, decides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This don't smell right. I'm callin'  Sheriff Wyner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chorus of gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam -- if you please. Yes! Yes! It  was a lie! A fantastic tale! You  have us! Dead to rights! But please  allow me to tell you the truth -- in  private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He escorts her to sit beneath the portrait of Othar, sits across from her, and leans confidentially in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He agonizes. The words do not come easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What I am about to reveal to you,  you may find... shocking. Mrs. Munson,  I must tell you that we are not...  what we appear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are not in fact musicians of the  late Renaissance. Nor of the early  or mid period. We are, in fact...  criminals! Desperate men, madam! We  have tunneled into the nearby offices  of the Lady Luck gambling emporium  and have relieved it of its treasure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord have mercy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is true that the Lady Luck is a  den of iniquity, a painted harlot  luring people into sin and exciting  the vice of greed with her false  promise of easy winnings. Oh, her  gains are ill-gotten, yes, but I  offer no excuses -- save one! We men  have each pledged half of our share  of the booty to a charitable  institution -- the General, to a  placement service for Southeast Asian  refugees; Mr. Pancake to the Blue  Ridge Parkway Conservancy; and Lump  to the United Jewish Appeal. As  compensation for use of your house  we had planned to donate a full share  to Bob Jones University, without  burdening you with guilty knowledge  by informing you of same. But you  have wrested the information from  me! Now it is all on the table. Now  you have it, the whole story, the  awful truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stolen money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, shamefully I admit it,  yes! But find the victim, Mrs. Munson,  I challenge you! Even the casino  itself, that riparian Gomorra, shall  suffer no harm! It has an insurance  company, a financial behemoth that  will cheerfully replenish its depleted  vaults! That is its function! And  the insurance company itself is made  up of tens and tens of thousands of  policy-holders so that -- we have  done the calculations, Mrs. Munson! --  so that at the end of the day, at  the final reckoning, each policy- holder shall have contributed only  one penny -- one single solitary  cent -- to the satisfaction of this  claim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Just one penny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of it, Mrs. Munson! One cent  from thousands upon thousands of  people so that Bob Jones University  can continue on its mission! Why, I  have no doubt that, were the policy- holders aware of the existence of  that august institution, why, each  and every one of them would have  volunteered some token amount to the  furtherance of its aims!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's prob'ly true...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Professor, warming, has resumed dry-washing his hands

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes madam, sadly, the criminal stain  is upon my soul, but the benefit  shall accrue to any number of worthy  causes. As long, that is, as the  secret stays with us. And I, surely,  shall not be the one to divulge it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson nods, musing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... it's hard to see the harm in  it... One penny...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her gaze drifts around the room, a smile beginning to war her face. The smile freezes, though, as her look catches something. Her POV: Othar, above the mantle, looks down with a  disapproving scowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm sorry, Professor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr is taken aback:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's wrong. Don't you be leadin'  me into temptation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam, I must strenuously protest--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's just plain wrong. Stealin'.  I know your intentions were good,  and I won't call the police if you  give the money back. But I gotta see  that you do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And all a you gotta go to church  with me next Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Professor is incredulous:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And... engage in divine worship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made up my mind. You can double- talk all you want, but its church or  the county jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it over. I gotta feed the  cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men all sit around the card table, lit from below by oil lamp. The General is neatly packing the stacks of  banknotes into the sackbutt case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motherfuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Unfortunately, Mrs. Munson has  rather complicated the situation--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how to discomplicate it! Put  a cap in the old lady's head! Then  everything simple again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group lapses into silence, considering. Even Gawain n a moment to digest the horror that he himself has propose The Professor is solemn:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Not easy to do. Many reasons.  Practical ones: a quiet neighborhood,  a sleepy town. Reasons of moral  repugnance: a harmless woman, a deed  conceived and executed in cold blood.  No, Gawain; would that it were simple!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- fuck, man! What we gonna do,  give the money back and go to church?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shudder. I quake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to the General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You sir, are a Buddhist. Is there  not a middle way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General grunts as he closes the clasps on the sackbut case full of money:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must float like a leaf on the river  of life. And kill old lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men murmur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I suppose you are right. It  is the active nature of the crime,  though, that so horrifies -- the  squeezing of the trigger, the plunging  of the knife. But, think a moment --  look at the other tools we have at  hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...We have the cellar. We have masonry  and trowel. Perhaps we could simply...  immure her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, easiest thing in the world. I  could whip up a little mortar in one  of those snow saucers, lay the bricks,  anchor in some chains, Mountain has  a source for the manacles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh but gentlemen, we delude  ourselves. Think of the woman's  piteous moans as we lay tier upon  tier of brick. Think of her  lamentations as we fit the last brick  into place, appealing to our better  selves, the higher angels of our  nature, our recollections of our own  sainted mothers... No, I fear that  we lack the sand to commit such an  act. No... no... shortest and most  painless is best. Let us confront  reality. Gawain's gun... the retort  muffled by a pillow... into the  brain... the affair of an instant.  The only question is... who wields  the weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around the table. Silence. No volunteers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I believe it is traditional, in  such circumstances, to draw straws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sure, fair enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a broom leaning against the wall, bends back and snaps a handful of its bristles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm thinking, though, that since  I lost my finger -- I mean, literally  lost it because of that goddamn cat --  maybe I should be excused from this  thing. Hard for me to squeeze a  trigger anyway--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You one whiney motherfucker! I squeeze  your nutsack you keep that up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, punk--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, no special pleading, no  exceptions. It's in the nature of  the situation that we would all prefer  to be excused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake grumbles as he counts out five bristles, takes on and snaps it in half, displaying the short straw to the g and then hands the four long and one short to the Profess

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, okay... it was just a trial  balloon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a flap of his cape the professor jumbles the straws encloses them in one hand. Sweaty CLOSE-UPS. Each man stares at the straws. Some  hesitant, some resolute, they draw: First, the General: long straw. His reaction: impassive. Next, Lump: long straw. His reaction: relieved. Next, Pancake. Long straw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long straw. You all see it. All your  fuss over nothing, punk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two straws left. Gawain stares at them, licks his lips. He reaches for one straw, touches it, hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Motherfucker...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He touches the other straw, hesitates. He goes back to the first straw, closes his hand around i closes his eyes, and pulls. He lifts the straw into frame before his squeezed-shut ey raises his eyebrows, and slowly opens fluttering eyelids look: short straw. The Professor, smiling, opens his fist to confirm that he holds the last long one. Gawain moans.

dialogues.speaker: PULLING HIM UP THE STAIRS
dialogues.text: Slowly, slowly, Gawain mounts the cellar stairs. Behind h gathered in a semi-circle and looking up from the foot of the stairs, the other men wait. As he plants one plodding foot in front of the other Gawa raises the gun, slides back its primer to make sure there a round in the chamber, and then slides it shut as he rea the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the foreground Mrs. Munson sits knitting, humming an o temperance tune. In the background the cellar door swings open. Marva Munson doesn't notice; her knitting needles  continue their rhythmic clack. We PULL Gawain, gun at the ready, as he takes slow, cauti steps across the floor. We INTERCUT his POV of the back of the old lady's head, b over her knitting. As Gawain passes the sofa he picks up a cushion and burie in it his hand holding the gun. He looks back up at the old lady. But now, still cautious approaching, he cocks his head, his expression bemused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: nearing the old lady is now different somehow. The perspe is somewhat lower; the humming woman sounds not quite the same; the rocking chair and the room itself are subtly  different.

dialogues.speaker: WHEN WE CUT BACK TO GAWAIN
dialogues.text: he is a runty, TEN-YEAR-OLD CHILD walking slowly across t floor; he is cradling not a gun in a pillow but a squirmi little puppy dog. The dog yips; the woman turns to look at us. It is not Mr Munson, but another black woman of about the same age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you got there, Gawain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why -- nothin', mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin' my ass! You got a dog there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mama!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A filthy noisy little pest of a puppy  dog gonna shit all over the house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't shit in the house, Mama,  I'm gonna train him, I promise, gonna  train him real good--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAP! She cuffs him on the side of his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna train you real good! I  told you don't bring no stray dogs  into this house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAP! Another slap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You wait til your Daddy gets home,  he gonna lay into you proper!

dialogues.speaker: WHAP
dialogues.text: The little boy, weeping, throws his arms around his mothe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't hurt me no more! I love  you, Mama!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy gonna kick your ass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Bringin' in a filthy dirty dog!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAP! Gawain's little brothers and sisters, drawn by the  commotion, have gathered excitedly to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama's whuppin' Gawain's ass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) Ain't you gonna use the strap, Mama?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAP! WHAP! Gawain is sobbing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't hurt me, Mama!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it is the adult Gawain blubbering. The clack of knitting needles stops and Mrs. Munson turns look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you doin'? What you doin' with  my pillow there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He surreptitiously slides the gun into his pocket, snivel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, ma'am, I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAP! She cuffs him on the side of the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm displeased with you! Colored boy  like you, falling in with that trash  downstairs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Ashamed a yourself! Didn't your  mama raise you right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain is tramping down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why... this is most... irregular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reminds me of my mama. I can't  shoot my mama! You motherfuckers  just draw straws again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. You've got to accept  your responsibilities, young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you. And your irritated bowel.  I can't shoot that old lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must shoot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look here, it's the easiest thing  in the world. Pretend her head is a  casaba melon, and the gun is a melon- baller, and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck you talkin' about,  man? You think this a melon-baller,  you do it, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My my, this is most irregular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, with equal rights come equal  responsibilities--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid that Mr. Pancake is right,  my dear fellow. We cannot draw straws  again; the exercise loses all  credibility if you show that the  loser can simply beg off doing the  job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must shoot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawain shoves the gun toward Pancake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just an old colored lady to you --  you do it, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you sniveling little coward!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you say, you whiney motherfucker?  I come up your irritated ass with  this -- motherfuckin' gun--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is waving the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you scare me, you mewling  punk! You don't scare me! Bull Connor  and all his dogs didn't scare me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoves Gawain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Be a man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoves him back. Pancake shoves:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be a man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't no fuckin' man, fuckin' a  sixty-year-old lady in pigtails!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHY YOU BASTARD PUNK! MOUNTAIN GIRL  IS FIFTY-THREE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are shoving each other now, getting into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...SHE COULD RIDE YOUR ASS TO JELLY!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lunges at him with a bear hug and his inertia sends bo men tumbling to the floor, where they roll and wrestle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seen Virginia hams I'd rather stick  my dick in than your old--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANG! A muffled gunshot. Quiet. The two men have stopped rolling. They stare at each other where they lie, Pancake on top. At length:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Oh my god...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horrified, he slowly rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I think he's hit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men gather round and look down. Gawain still stares up at the ceiling. Pancake stoops, waves his hand in front of his eyes. No  reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'll just check the carotid artery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He checks the carotid artery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That's a negative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he dead, Professor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure he's dead. I checked his carotid  artery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well this is most irregular. We will  need a Hefty bag.
