dialogues.speaker: THE CELLAR DOOR
dialogues.text: Creaking open. The Professor, Lump, and the General peek  out. The living room is empty but a sliver of the kitchen is  visible; its light is on, and we can hear water running. Dorr hisses:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is in the kitchen. I shall  distract her while you steal out  with the carcass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr enters breezily; Mrs. Munson is at the sink, filling teapot. Dorr positions himself so that, to talk to him, Mrs. Muns has her back to the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, my dear Mrs. Munson, I have  outlined your position to my  colleagues and I now return to you  to return our collective verdict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind her, the General peers around the corner and start catlike advance across the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was much spirited discussion  and an atmosphere of frank give-and- take. Some of our number were  initially appalled at your proposal  that we simply return the money;  some were more receptive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care they was receptive or  not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that attitude, madam, was a factor  in our discussions. To a man, I must  say, they were devastated at the  prospect of not being able to  contribute to their respective  charities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General signals to Lump who now crosses the living ro with a big garbage bag slung over one shoulder in a firem carry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that is a shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed. But at the end of the day,  your position prevailed, and the men  have decided that we shall return  the money -- every last cent of it! --  and attend Sunday services, rather  than spend the remainder of our years  wasting away in the Mississippi Men's  Correctional Facility. Though that  was the original preference of some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'm glad y'all came to see the  light, anyway. I'm gonna have some  tea and go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Professor, seeing that the General and Lump have made out the door, is anxious to wind things up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the money shall be returned  tomorrow at the opening of the casino  office. Enjoy your tea, madam...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Backing out, he looks to one side. Through the living room window he can see the hearse pull away from the curb. There is another car -- an old Volksw microbus -- slowly tooling the opposite way down the stre Dorr looks back to Mrs. Munson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and congratulations on having  recalled to the fold five poor,  confused sheep who had momentarily  strayed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are at the middle of the bridge, the tower gargoyle lo blankly down at the doings below. In the misty night Lump and the General are braced over t railing, looking down, each holding one of the feet that  protrude from the Hefty bag cinched around Gawain's ankle A cigarette burns on the General's lower lip. Behind the men we can see the idling hearse. There is the toot of the garbage scow. Lump and the Gener release Gawain's feet. Their POV shows the sack receding and flumping into the  garbage piled onto the scow that slips by below. A flock of scavenger birds, disturbed by the impact, lift off the scow with angry caws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr skulks at a corner of the living room's picture wind peering out at the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Volkswagon microbus again cruises slowly down the str in the same direction as previously; apparently it has be circling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Professor scowls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hearse pulls up to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Professor clomps down the cellar stairs. Pancake is  loading their digging implements into a satchel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They back yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorr is absent:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... yes, they just arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancake straightens from the satchel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. I'll go dump these in the  hearse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mounts the stairs with a satchel in either hand. We ca hear the front door opening as the other men enter. Dorr, bemused, but apparently moved by a hunch, advances  slowly to the sackbutt case. He slides the catch that lets its spring clasp pop up. He lifts the lid. Mother Jones magazine. Piles of Mother Jones magazines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in heaven's name...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He riffles a pile, confirming that it is in fact all maga no money. Lump and the General are clomping down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...General!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are PULLING Clark down the street, a satchel in either hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The microbus, parked halfway down the block, ominously id

dialogues.speaker: THE BUS
dialogues.text: We are CLOSE on its side-view mirror. Someone leans from driver's seat for a view into the mirror, and in the mirr we see her, pigtails swinging: Mountain Girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark Pancake, still rather small, approaching up the emp street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULLING him again. A smile is beginning to play at the co of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No extra share, huh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smile abruptly fades. He stops in his tracks for no discernible reason. At leng

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Nnnrnf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pants. Behind him, in the deep background, we see the General  bounding into the street and silently toward us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Oof!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moment passes. Pancake shakes his head, as if to clea it, and resumes his walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are nearing the bus.

dialogues.speaker: THE BUS
dialogues.text: Mountain Girl sits in the idling bus, waiting. With a thunk and a gentle rock of the bus, we hear its ba doors opening, and Pancake's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear an oof! of exertion as Pancake hoists each of the two satchels into the back. The oofs are followed by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Nnrungh! Aaarmh... Ninnnff...  Offffflleghhll...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IBS, dear?

dialogues.speaker: THE BACK OF THE BUS
dialogues.text: to show Pancake being garotted by the General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nnnnnmmmmfffgh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tower gargoyle stares sightlessly down. Lump and the General are at their accustomed place, each  holding a foot shod in a large hiking boot. Behind them we see the hearse idling. Near them on the bridge, both hands grasping the railing he gazes dreamily out into the night, is the Professor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...Like those Nicean barks of yore  That gently, o'er a perfumed sea..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the toot of the boat's horn and the men drop the  body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick! Grab Clark!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They quickly stoop and grab another bag-swaddled body out which even larger hiking boots protrude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...The weary, wayworn wanderer  bore... "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drop the second body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...To his own native shore."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the distant flump and the cawing of scavenger bir

dialogues.speaker: A FIST
dialogues.text: With three protruding straws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lump picks a long straw: relief. The General picks a short straw. A short grunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent. I believe, at last, we  have the right man for the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson lies on her back gently snoring. At the open  window, sheers ripple in the evening breeze. A large clock ticks upon the mantle. It is almost one o'c

dialogues.speaker: THE CELLAR DOOR
dialogues.text: It creaks open. The General looks stealthily out. A cigar in his mouth plumes smoke. He pushes the door fully open, emerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson's snore catches on an inhale. She mutters  something, sighs, and resumes snoring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General treads lightly, noiselessly, up the stairway  leading to the second floor. He slides one hand into his  jacket, pulls out a garotte. With the faintest whoosh he whips it in a complicated loo and snags the other handle with his other hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General emerges from the staircase and advances on th closed bedroom door. As he reaches for the knob he perfor the no-handed flip of the burning cigarette into his mout

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door swings noiselessly open. The General pauses to  survey: The still room. The ticking clock. Mrs. Munson, a large  sleeping mound upon the bed. The General advances, raising the garotte in both hands. He closes on her sleeping form. The garotte is lowered toward her exposed neck. It is a foot -- half a foot -- inches-away... Somewhere a muted gear ratchets and triggers the toll of- The clock, striking one. It is a cuckoo clock but, instea of a bird emerging, a berobed Jesus comes out with his ha resting on the head of a child who gazes up in adoration. The General starts at the noise and then suddenly freezes his eyes widening. Jesus retreats back into the clock. The General has swallowed his cigarette. He reaches up to his throat, panicked. In a silent frenzy he yanks loose his ascot. He gazes wildly about. He reaches for the water glass at Mrs. Munson's bedside. He tips it back into his mouth. There is a rattling sound

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The uptilted water glass is sending false teeth -- full u and lowers -- rattling toward his face.

dialogues.speaker: THE GENERAL
dialogues.text: He frantically -- but still noiselessly -- sets the glass back down. Wildly looks about, one hand clamped to his th A mad but silent dash for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plunging for the head of the stairs-- --a brief yowl from the cat-- --recoiling from where its tail has been stepped on, a hi and a flash of its claws at the General's leg--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and he falls down the stairs, each thudding impact boun his body like a rag doll's. At the bottom of the stairs he lies still. A CLOSE-UP shows his head bent at an unnatural angle,  unblinking eyes staring. Traces of smoke wisp from each  nostril and his open mouth. Over the mantle, Othar returns the dead man's stare. He l somewhat smug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Professor and Lump, responding to the noise, look slo up toward the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The body is laid out in a garbage bag by the rail. The Professor stands looking at it, contemplatively. Lump stands looking at it, contemplatively. The cat sits nearby on its haunches looking at it,  impassively. The professor muses:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...T'was our atГ© brought us to this  pass...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, Professor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the toot! of an approaching scow. Dorr's manner still absent, his regard still on the corpse:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our overweening pride... The old  woman is a more potent antagonist  than one had imagined...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rouses himself, goes over to the bagged corpse. Lump  follows him and the two men hoist the body over the rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Now, Lump, I'm afraid it falls to  you to finish the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They let the body fall onto the scow passing below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The comedy must end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Professor turns to Lump and tries to hand him Gawain' gun, but Lump, uncomfortable, declines to take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Professor, I been doing some  thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear. Oh dear oh dear oh dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she's right! Maybe we should  be going to church!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear, Lump. I feared that those  would be your words. Not that I don't  appreciate your giving the matter  the benefit of your thought. But  please recall, young man, our  respective functions in this  enterprise. I am a professor, the  professor as you yourself so often  say, the thinker, the "brains of the  operation," trained in fact in the  arts of cogitation. You, Lump, are  the goon, the hooligan, the dumb  brute whose actions must be directed  by a higher intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know, but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No buts, dear boy! Do not repeat the  error of thinking! Now is the moment  of praxis! Now, my dear boy, you  must act!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lump reluctantly takes the gun that the Professor thrusts upon him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do it, Professor! A nice old  lady like that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of the riches, Lump, that you  and I alone shall divide! Recall the  dream of wealth untold that first  drew you to this enterprise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And reflect also that if you decline  to act, forcing me to do so, then  you shall no longer have any  entitlement to the money! Your offices  shall have been nugatory!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean -- you mean -- you're gonna  kill her?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course! My hand would be forced!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't let you do that, Professor!  A nice old lady like that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?! Allow? Not allow? What  presumption! You stupid boy! You  very very extremely stupid boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the toot of an approaching scow -- this one very  long, sustained under all of the following:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points the gun at the Professor and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well who looks stupid now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --squeezes -- click -- on an empty chamber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns the gun to have a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...No bullets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shows the foreshortened barrel as he experimentally squee the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the Professor on the BANG! and, after a sad shake of his  head,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lump in time to see him finish toppling back over the rai The scow-horn ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps... it had to be thus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the railing to look down. Lump, face-up on a pile of garbage, glides away. Disturbe birds flap upward. The professor muses:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...Lo, in yon brilliant window-niche  How statue-like I see thee stand..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His gaze rises with the ascending birds. Among the white gulls is one black bird. The Professor ey it as it rises past him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hm. A raven?

dialogues.speaker: FROM VERY HIGH
dialogues.text: we look down on the Professor, the black bird rising to p on the gargoyle on the suspension tower in the foreground The bird settles on a loose, teetering piece of masonry.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: looking at the receding red light on the bridge of the  receding scow:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...The agate lamp within thy hand...  "

dialogues.speaker: BACK HIGH
dialogues.text: The teetering chunk of masonry tips away and the perchles bird flaps off.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: very dreamy: he sees something in the distance, beyond ti and space:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Ah, Psyche! from the regions which  Are Holy land!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is punctuated by the crunching impact of masonry sco a direct hit on his head. He falls over the rail. His cape snags on the railing and he hangs limp and lifel Directly below his dangling body the stern of Lump's barg is slipping away to leave black waters and the clanking o chains. The fabric of the Professor's cape begins to tear. His bo drops in fits and starts as the fabric gives way. Finally the body rips free. It falls away from us. As it  does so the clanking chains are pulling into view the sec banger -- a garbage barge being chain-towed by the recedi scow. Dorr's body lands neatly on the barge. A gust of wind. The cape flaps free of the railing and is wind-tossed awa amidst the cawing birds. The cat, watching, blinks.

dialogues.speaker: DRINKING GLASS
dialogues.text: It is resting on the very edge of the night table --  protruding, in fact, past the table's edge. It is morning. We hear rustling from the bed. Hands reach INTO FRAME and hesitate, finding the glass em of water and precariously perched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hands tip the glass and take the teeth. We hear  complicated oral noises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens away to reveal the morning paper lying on stoop. Mrs. Munson leans INTO FRAME to pick it up and we  ADJUST as she straightens to have a look: The headline says: $2.6 MILLION DISAPPEARS FROM LADY LUCK CASINO. The subhead: POLICE BAFFLED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson is walking down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops midway down and looks: The empty cellar. Money stacked neatly on the card table. Mrs. Munson sadly shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hmm. Couldn't face the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson is climbing the porch in her Sunday best. She feints at the dog who lies curled in the sun:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scoot now! Outa the way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheriff is busy on the phone; there is a DEPUTY today also on the phone. The sheriff, seeing Mrs. Munson enter, covers the phone with one hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miz Munson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff, I gotta make a statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could it possibly wait, ma'am? We're  a little busy today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it can wait, but it's about  that casino money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheriff exchanges a significant look with the deputy, then murmurs into the phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call you right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cradles the phone and smiles at Mrs. Munson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You know something about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something? Everything! I got it at  home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You... you have what at home, now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The money. Two point six million  dollars. Down in my root cellar. All  stacked up nice and neat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deputy pauses to look up from his phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd it get there, Marva?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bunch a desperate men that stole it  put it there, that's how! They was  musicians of the Renaissance period,  played the sackbutt and so on --  well, it turns out they really  couldn't play, although they could  recite poems to break your heart.  Their ringleader speaks in dead  tongues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to get you to see him! That  night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to yell at 'em 'bout stealin'  all that money and I guess I made  'em feel pretty bad 'cause they picked  up and left without takin' the money.  But I was peeved with 'em, Sheriff,  they'd been up to all sorts of  mischief, come close to blowin' up  the house, disturbed Othar no end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angry, was he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you be? All that racket!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expect so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they let Pickles out too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheriff sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you want us to go fetch him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's back, but what you want me  to do with the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and the deputy exchange looks. The sheriff looks back Mrs. Munson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Why don't you just keep it, Miz  Munson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep it, Marva.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I know it's only a penny  offa everybody's policy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know folks don't much care. Could  I... You s'pose I could...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I give it all to Bob Jones  University?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'd be nice, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up her handbag and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, long as everybody knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for the information, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome, sheriff. Just doin'  my duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Munson is walking home. It is a beautiful spring day From far off, wafting toward us on the breeze, we can hea the church chorus singing. Mrs. Munson joins in. She has strong voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaning, Leaning, Safe and secure  from all harm. Lean on Jesus, Lean  on Jesus, Leaning on the everlasting  arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns up the walk to her house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What a fellowship, What a peace  of mind, Safe and secure from all  harm. Lean on Jesus, Lean on Jesus,  Leaning on the everlasting arm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she opens the front door the cat slips out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Pickles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It races off down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Pickles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pickles scurries along the walkway. We hear the toot! of approaching scow. The cat reaches the middle of the bridge. He sticks his h through the bars of the railing. When we CUT CLOSE on the cat as he looks down at the wate we see that he holds in his mouth a human finger. As the scow passes underneath, the cat opens its mouth an lets the finger drop. The finger falls away and is barely visible by the time i hits the scow. The cat looks up INTO THE LENS, and blinks. Its sideways  irises adjust. The scow is gliding away. With the low mournful toot of i horn we tilt up the river to the great garbage island whe scavenger birds pick through the trash.
